If there are no victories in battle,
the defenses will not be secure.
If the defenses are not secure,
enemy countries will control [his state].
This being so, what would the former kings do?
The answer is:
They would not, because of the six [attacks], alter their commanDs and orders,
create doubts about [the certainty of their] using battle-axes and halberds,
or tamper with salaries and rewards.
Such being the case,
the near and far were of one mind
Being of one mind,
the many and the few cooperated int heir efforts.
Cooperating in their efforts,
they were certain to be victorious in battle
and the defenses were certain to be secure.
This was not to annex and plunder,
but to provide government for the entire realm.
This is the way to bring order to the realm.
If [the rewards and punishments] are reliable yet [the orders] are not carried out,
it is because [the ruler] does not set an example [by obeying them] himself.
Therefore, it is said:
'When prohibitions take preceedence over [the ruler] himself,
his orders will be carried out among the people.'
To hear of worthiness and not elevate it
is dangerous.
To hear of excellence and not seek after it
is dangerous.
To see ability and not employ it
is dangerous.
To become intimate with men and not remain firm [of purpose]
is dangerous.
To agree on a plan and then diverge from it
is dangerous.
To make threats against others and not be able [to implement them]
is dangerous.
To dismiss a person and then reinstate him
is dangerous.
To fail to act when there is an opportunity to do so
is dangerous.
To have secret plans and not treat them discreetly
is dangerous.
If the ruler of men is not discreet in all things,
gentlemen who would speak truthfully and act in a straightforward manner will be endangered.1
If the gentlemen who would speak truthfully and act in a straightforward manner are endangered,
the ruler of men will find himself isolated and without an inner circle of supporters.
If the ruler of men is isolated and without an inner circle of supporters,
his ministers will form factions and assemble their partisans.
If the ruler of men becomes isolated and without an inner circle of supporters
and his ministers form factions and assemble their partisans,
this is not the crime of his ministers
but rather is the fault of the ruler himself.
If the people do not commit serious crimes,
it is because they have committed no major faults.
If the people have committed no major faults,
it is because the sovereign has granted no pardons.
If the sovereign pardons minor faults,
the people will go on to commit many serious crimes.
This is because [the latter] grow out of an acumulation [of the former].
Therefore it is said:
'If pardons are granted, the people will not be respectful,2
and if mercy is bestowed, their faults will daily increase.'
If mercy and pardon are extended to the people,
then even though the prisons are full
and executions numerous,
depravity will not be overcome.
Therefore it is said:
'There is nothing better than preventing depravity at its inception.'
In general11 the granting of pardons
is of little benefit and of great harm,
and in the long run nothing is more disastrous.
The nongranting of pardons
is of little harm and great benefit,
and in the long run nothing can be more beneficial.
Thus granting pardons
is the same as releasing the reins of a runaway horse,
while not granting them
is the same as [probing] a festering boil12 with a stone lancet.13
In civil affairs one may be lenient17 three times,
but in military affairs not a single pardon should be granted.
One who is merciful grants many pardons.
At first this is easy but later it becomes difficult,
and in the long run nothing is more disastrous.
The person who adheres to the law grants no pardons.18
At first this is difficult, but it becomes easy
and in the long run nothing is more beneficial.
Therefore, he who shows mercy is the enemy of the people,
while he who adheres to the law is the father and mother of the people.
It is best to institute regulations and procedures [which will prevent any errors].
Next best is to be able to catch mistakes should they occur.
Then, even though there may be errors,
they will not be very serious.
If faults are pardoned and excellence neglected,
the people will not be encouraged.
Faults should not be pardoned;
excellence should not be neglected.3
The way to encourage the people
lies in the application of this [principle].
Therefore it is said:
'The enlightened prince is a keen judge of affairs.'
The prince desires three things from his people,
but if these desires are not kept within bounds,
his position on high will be endangered.
What are the three?
The first pertains to what he seeks,
the secont to what he prohibits,
and the third to what he orders.
He certainly desires to gain what he seeks.
He certainly desires to have stopped what he prohibits.
He certainly desires to have carried out what he orders.
If he seeks too much,
little wil be gained.
If he prohibits too much,
little will be stopped.
If he orders too much,
little will be carried out.
If what he seeks is not gained,
his prestige will daily decrease.
If what he prohibits is not stopped,
the punishments wil be ridiculed.
If what he orders is not carried out,
his subjects will have humiliated the sovereign.
Thus it is that no one has ever been able to seek too much and gain it all,
prohibit too much and have all that is prohibited stopped,
or issue too many orders and have them all carried out.
Therefore it is said:
'If the sovereign is too demanding, his subjects will not be obedient.'
If subjects, being disobedient, are forced [to conform] by means of punishments,
the masses will scheme against anyone who becomes the sovereign.
When someone becomes the sovereign and the masses scheme against him,
he cannot possibly avoid danger,
even though he may want to.
If orders are changed
once they have been issued,
if rules of propriety and righteousness are abandoned
once they are put into practice,
if procedures and measurements are altered
once they have been institued,
if penal laws are modified
once they are in place,
then
even though the rewards are generous,
the people will not be encouraged,
and even though there are many executions,
the people will not be fearful.
Therefore it is said:
'If the sovereign lacks af firm purpose,4
his subjects will harbor doubts in their hearts,
and if the state lacks constant standards,
the strength of the people will certainly be exhausted.
This is inevitable.'
When an enlightened prince occupies the position on high,
there will be no one among the people who will dare initiate private debates or consider himself better than others.
Within the country there will be no monstorus boasts,5
heterodox customs,
or peculiar rites.
Among gentlemen there will be no private debates.
Those who display arrogance, alter the orders,
lay down their own rules of conduct,
draw up their own regulations
or engage in private debates
will all be punished.6
Thus the strong will be bent,
the sharp blunted,
and the firm broken.7
He will guide them with the marking line [of the law]
and set them straight with punishments.
Thus the hearts of all the people will be subservient and they will follow their sovereign.
When he pushes them, they will go;
when he pulls them, they will come.
If, however, there are among his subjects any who initiate private debates or consider themselves better than others
or any who are quarrelsome and draw themselves apart,
the orders will not be carried out.
Therefore it is said:
'When private debates are initiated, the way of the ruler will be debased.'
How much more will this be true8 if there are any who are arrogant, alter the orders,
lay down their own rules of conduct, draw up their own regulations,
change the customs,
wear strange clothes, voice heretical theories, or set themselves apart.9
Those who on high do not carry out the prince's orders,
who are uncooperative in the districts and villages below,
who act on their own to change things,
and who alter the established customs of the country -
these are called people who cannot be sheperded.
People who cannot be shepherded
stand outside the marking line [of the law]
and should be punished.10
See to it that worthy men are given salaries according to their ability
and fighting knights according to their achievements.
If worthy men are given salaries according to their ability,
the sovereign will be honored and the people obedient.
If fighting knights are given salaries according to their achievements,
troops will disregard fortune and scorn the enemy.
If these two things - the sovereign being honored and the people being obedient,
the troops disregarding misfortune and scorning the enemy -
are achieved within the country,
the realm may be well governed and the ruler made secure.
If a person has neither high rank
nor a large salary
he will not share in preparing for difficulties or withstanding danger.
When he is treated in such a way, nothing can be expected from him.
For his reason, former kings instituted official carriages and caps
that were just adequate enough14 to distinguish the honored from the lowly,
but they did not strive for beauty.
They established ranks and salaries
just adequate enough to insure service,
but they did not strive for ostentatiousness.
They caused men of quality to be paid in accordance with [their adherence to] the moral way
and ordinary men in accordance with their physical effort.15
When men of quality are paid in accordance with their [adherence to] the moral way,
the sovereign is honored and the people submissive.
When ordinary men are paid in accordance with their physical effort,
wealth becomes abundant and nourishment adequate.
When these four [conditions] have been fulfilled -
the sovereign honored, the people submissve,
wealth abundant, and norishment adequate -
then by awaiting the proper opportunity,16 it is easy to become king.
The enlightened prince builds his ancestral temple
just adequate enough to provide for the guests19 at sacrifical feasts,
but does not strive for [lavish] beauty.
He erects palaces and pavillions
just adequate enough to avoid dryness and dampness, cold and heat,
but does not strve for grandiosity.
He sees that their carvings and engravings
are just adequate enough to differentiate between the honored and lowly,
but does not strive for ostentatiousness.
Thus, the peasants do not neglect their seasonal occupations,
the various artisans do not neglect their work,
the merchants do not lose their profits,
the people have no idle days,
and wealth is not hoarded.20
Therefore it is said:
'Frugality is the way.'21
It22 is reckless of the sovereign
to reward people
who have acted on orders before they have been issued.
If the sovereign rewards thus recklessly,
meritorious ministers will become resentful.
If meritorioius ministers become resentful,
stupid people will administer affairs in a reckless manner.
If stupid people administer affairs in a reckless manner,
it will form the basis of great confusion.
[On the other hand], it is reckless of the sovereign
to mete out punishments before orders have been issued.
If the sovereign metes out punihsments recklessly, the people will have little regard for life.
If the people have little regard for life, men of violence will flourish,
factions will arise, and rebelions occur.
If the orders have already been issued but no rewards follow,
the people will become discouraged,
no longer follow the regulations,
or be willing to sacrifice their lives [for the sovereign].
If such
is the case,
they will neither be victorious in attack nor firm in defense.
If they are neither victorious in attack nor firm in defense,
the country will indeed not be safe.
If orders have already been issued but punishments are not meted out [to those who disregard them],
the people are taught to be disobedient.
If the people are taught to be disobedient,
the strong establish themselves [in power].
If the strong establish themselves,
the position of the ruler will be endangered.
Therefore it is said:
'Legal statutes, regulations, and procedures must be patterned on the moral way,
the orders must be publicized and made clear,
and the rewards and punishments must be made reliable and absolute.'23
These are the standards for bringing order to people.
The prince of a great country is always honored,
while the prince of a small country is held in low esteem.
Why
is the prince of a great country honored?
The answer is
that there are many in his employ.
Why
is the prince of a small country held in low esteem?
The answer is
that there are few in his employ.
Thus, if one is honored because of employing many
and held in low esteem because of employing few,
how can a ruler fail to want the masses of the people employed on his behalf?
What are the means for employing the masses of the people on one's behalf?
The answer is
that when laws are established and orders carried out,
many of the people will be employed.
But if laws are not established
and orders are not carried out,
few of the people will be employed.
Therefore, if many laws are establised
and many orders carried out
whereas only a few are disregarded,
the people will not engage in slanderous talk.
If the people do not engage in slanderous talk,
they will be obedient.
If laws that have been established
and orders that have been carried out
eare equal in number to those that have been disregarded,
the country will lack constant standards.
If the country lacks constant standards,
the people will act recklessly.
If few laws are established
and few orders carried out
whereas many are disregarded,
the people will not be obedient.
If they are not obedient,
men of violence will arise and depravity will become prevalent.
If one assesses the reason why a sovereign loves his people,
it is because he employs them.
But if, because of loving them,
he feels no reluctance toward underminisng laws or neglecting orders,
he will in this case fail in what is truly loving the people.
If he fails24 to love the people when employing them,
it will soon become evident that the people are not being employed.
Now he who is skilled25 in employing the people
may kill them, endanger them,.
belabor them, make them suffer,26
starve them, or exhaust them.
His employment of the people may bring them to thee extremes,
yet no one among them will conspire to harm him.27
When an enlightened king is on the throne,
laws patterned on the moral way are carried out throughout the country,
and the people all set aside what they like so as to do what they dislike.
Therefore, he who is skilled in employing the people
does not take low rank into consideration when bestowing official carriages and caps
nor is he influenced by high position when applying the axe and halberd.
In such a way,
worthy men are encouraged while men of violence are kept in check.
If worthy men are encouraged and men of violence kept in check,
[the sovereign's] merit and fame will be established for posterity.
People will tread on naked blades,
suffer arrows and stones,28
and enter water and fire
in order to obey the orders of their sovereign.
When the orders of the sovereign are completely carried out
and his prohibitions are completely effective,
he may draw the people into service
and they wil not dare shirk their work.
He may push them into battle
and they dare not refuse to die.
When men dare not shirk their work,
only then will there be achievement.
When men dare not refulse to die,
only then will [the sovereign] be unrivaled [in battle].
Advancing, he will be unrivaled,
withdrawing, he will be successful.
Hence the men in his three armies29
will be able to preserve their heads and necks
while their fathers and mothers, wives and children
remain completely safe at home.
Now the people should never be allowed to share in the consideration [of an undertaking] at its inception,
but they may be allowed to join in the rejoicing over its successful completion.30
For this reason those who are humane, understanding, and possess the moral way
will not share with others31 any consideration of [an affiar] at its inception.
It is not because of its small size and misfortunes that a country suffers paring away [of its territory] or meets with destruction.
Rather it is sure to be because virtuous conduct has been neglected by the ruler and his great ministers;
because official duties, legal regulations, and political instruction have been neglected within the country;
and because the schemes of the feudal lords have been neglected abroad.32
It is because of this that territory is pared away and the country is imperiled.33
It is not because of its large size and good fortune that a country achieves sucess and fame.
Rather it is sure to be because virtuous conduct has been practiced by the ruler and his great ministers;
because official duties, legal regulations, and political instruction have been maintained within the country;
and because the schemes of the feudal lords have been dealt with abroad.34
It is only then that success may be established and fame achieved.
Thus, how can a country get along without the moral way
or men get along without seeking after it?35
If [the ruler] finds the moral way and guides his people with it
and if he finds worthy men and employs them,
he may achieve his great expectations of promoting benefit and expelling harm.
But in achieving such expectations
nothing is more vital than his own conduct.
Moreover, if the prince stans alone and comes to extreme harm,
it is sure to be because he has neglected his previous orders.36
If the ruler of men neglects his orders, he will be kept in ignorance [of what is going on].
If he is kept in ignorance, he will be stripped of his power.
If he is stripped of his power, he will be assasinated.
What makes a prince of men a prince
is always his position of authority.
Therefore, if he loses this position of authority,
his ministers will control him.
When the position of authority rests with his subordinate officials,
the prince is controlled by his ministers,
whereas when it rests with the sovereign,
the ministers are controlled by the prince.
Therefore, when the prince and his ministers exchange positions,
authority rests with his subordinates.
Should it rest with the ministers for a year,
then even though the ministers may prove to be disloyal,
the prince will not be able to retrieve it.
Should it rest with a son for a year,
then even though the son may prove to be unfilial,
the father will not be able to bring him to submission.
Thus, in the records of the Chūnqiú
there are cases of ministers who murdered their princes
and sons who murdered their fathers.37
Therefore it is said:
'Those who stand at the head of the hall38 may be further away than 100 lǐ;
those at the foot of the hall, 1,000 lǐ;
those at the gate, 10,000 lǐ.'
Now, by taking a single day's tour on foot
one may come to know conditions within 100 lǐ,
but if those who stand at the head of the hall have business
and yet after ten days the prince has not heard them,
it may be said that they are further away than 100 lǐ.
By taking a ten-day tour on foot
one may come to know conditions within 1,000 lǐ,
but if those who stand at the head of the hall have business
and yet after one month the prince still has not heard them,
it may be said they are further away than 1,000 lǐ.
By taking a hundred-day tour on foot
one may come to know conditions within 10,000 lǐ,
but if those who stand at the gate have business
and yet after one year the prince has not heard them,
it may be said they are further away than 10,000 lǐ.
Therefore, when information39 has been sent in but there is no outgoing reply,
it is said to have been supressed.
When [information] has been sent out but there is no incoming confirmation,
it is said to have been cut off.
When [information] has been sent in but does not reach [as far as the court],
it is said to have been intercepted.
When [information] has been sent out but is stopped on he way,
it is said to have been blocked.
When a prince [is plagued by information] being supressed, cut off, intercepted, and blocked,
it is not because he has shut his gates and guarded his door,
but because his administration is not functioned properly.
Therefore it is said:
'Orders are more precious than jewels.
The altars of Land and Grain take preceedence over family relations.
The laws are more important than the people.
Prestige and power are more to be valued than ranks and salaries.'
Thus, do not disregard orders because of precious jewels.
Do not consider your altars of Land and Grain secondary because of family relations.
Do not twist laws and statutes because of love for the people.
Do not share your prestige and power because of ranks and salaries.
Therefore it is said:
'Your position of authority is not something to be granted to others.'
To govern
means to establish a correct order.40
The establishment of a correct order
serves to correct and fix the terminologǜ1 of all things.
For this reason the sage refines his virtue and takes a central stand in order to bring about the correct order.
He makes this correct order clear [to the people] so that the state will be well governed.
Therefore the establishment of a correct order is the means to check what goes too far and push forward what falls too short.
Neither what goes too far nor what falls too short
is correct.
Since neither is correct
they are alike in harming the country.42
Bravery without righteousness
is harmful to the armed forces.
Humaneness without correctness
is harmful to the law.43
Therefore military defeat
may spring from lack of righteousness.
Transgression of the law
may spring from lack of correct order.
So it is that speech may be argumentative and irresponsible,
and conduct troublesome and evil.
Therefore, in speech one must be responsible
and not given to needless argument.
In action one must think of what is good
and not be given to needless troublemaking.
The compass and T-square are
[instruments for achieving] correctness in making squares and circles.
Even though one may have a clever eye and a skillful hand,
these are no match for correctness of the simple compass and T-square.
Therefore a clever person is able to produce a compass and T-square
but is unable to make correct squares and circles without them.44
[In the same way] even the sage, though able to produce laws,
is unable to put the state in order without them.
Therefore, even though a person may be of brilliant wisdom and exemmplary conduct,
for him to attempt to put [the state] in order while turning his back on the laws
be like trying to make correct squares and circles without a compass and T-square.

and sons who murdered their fathers.

laxity,

Another version says:
When worthy men are not presented,

When loyal ministers are not employed,

When [the ruler] issues orders that are not carried out,

When the people follow the sovereign,
they never follow merely what his mouth says

the people will not be afraid of death.
If the sovereign likes goodness,

In all discussions about [the relative merits of] men, there are certain essential points:
No great gentlemen
will be found among men given to boasting.
Those given to boasting
[consider themselves] perfect,
but their perfection
is hollow.
Perfection or hollowness is a matter of facts,
and the facts are what decide the matter.
Those given to boasting
belong to the category of petty men.
No gentlemen of high standing will be found among those who repudiate the past
when discussing the present,52
and no gentlemen of [great] wisdom will be found among those who are ignorant of the past
and are easygoing in their achievements.
Even though one may be completely virtuous in his own conduct, if he repudiates the past
he will be a mediocre person.53
Those who lack natural talent in affairs
and who, in spite of good opportunities, are careless in their duties,
are gentlemen of low mentality.
No gentlemen of worth are to be found
among men who fish for fame.
No kingly rulers are to be found
among princes who fish for profit.
In conducting himself, the worthy man
forgets about fame.
In carrying out the moral way, the kingly ruler
forgets about achieving success.
Nothing can hinder
the conduct of the worthy man
or the moral way of the kingly ruler.
The enlightened prince rules the country for the public good and unites the people so as to gain the obedience of the realm.
The loyal minister advances in a straightforward manner so as to have his ability judged.
The enlightened prince does not grant salaries and ranks to those he [merely] likes personally.
The loyal minister does not make false claims of abilities in order to seek ranks and salaries.
The prince should not rule the country in his own interest
and the minister whould not make false claims about his ability.
Even though adherence to this way
may not produce great government,
it does provide a [constant] standard for establishing correct order among the people.
Now, from ancient times down to the present,
success and fame have never been attained
when a prince who ruled the country for his own interest
was served by a minister who falsified his own ability.
Men who falsify their ability are easily known.
Ministers54 should be measured by [the example of] those of the former kings.
When Shun possessed the world,
Yu was his minister of works (sīkōng),
Xie was minister of education (sītú),
Gaoyao was chief justice (lǐ),
and Houji was minister of agriculture (tián).55
These four gentlemen
were the worthiest men in the world;
still, in serving their prince
each was esteemed for refining his one particular virtue.
Nowadays men who falsify their ability
to carry out affairs and fulfil their offices
all try to combine the abilities of these four worthies.
From this point of view,
it is easy to see
that they will achieve neither succes not fame.
but provided their ranks are honored and their salaries large,
there is nothing they will not put up with.
Provided their positions are profitable and their offices important,
there is no one they will not follow.
He who serves the prince in such a way
is known as the minister who falsifies ability and grasps for profit.
If in the world ther is no prince who rules his country for the public good,
there will be no gentlemen who will advance in a straightforward manner.
If there are no rulers56 who judge the abilities [of their ministers],
there will be no successful ministers.
When the three dynasties passed from one to another in ancient times,
the killing took place in the same world [we have today].57
Nothing impoverishes the people or destroys goods
on such a scale as do armed forces.
Nothing endangers the country or causes the ruler concern
as quickly as do armed forces.
These four evil consequences are clear,
yet from ancient times to the present, no one has been able to dispense with [armed forces].
Not to dispense with armed forces when they ought to be dispensed with.
shows confusion.58
But to wish to dispense with armed forces
when they ought not to be dispensed with,59
likewise shows confusion.
These two situations
are alike in their harm to the country.
Huang Di, Tang, and Yu60
were the most glorious emperors.
They possessed the entire realm
and its control lay in the hands of a single man.
Yet [even] during this time
armed forces were not dispensed with.
Nowadays, since the virtue [of our rulers] does not come up to that of these three emperors
and the world is not obedient,
would it not be difficult
to dispense with armed forces?
Therefore, the enlightened prince knows where to assume responsibility
and what will have evil consequences.
Seeing to it that the state is kept in good order and the people pay attention to their harvest -
this is where he assumes responsibility.
[Unsuitable] movement or rest -

when hungry, relax your thoughts;
when old, forget614 your worries.
If, having eaten too much, you do not quickly move about,
The breath will not circulate to your four extremeties.
If, being hungry, you do not relax your thoughts,
Your hunger will not be alleviated.615
If, being old, you do not forget your worries,
when troubled,616 you will be quickly exhausted.
Expand your mind, and you will feel release.
Deepen your breathing, and you will feel relaxed.
Your form will be at ease and never restless.
You will be able to focus your power of awareness, and dispose of the myriad minor irritations.
On seeing profit, you will not be enticed.
On seeing harm, you will not be frightened.617
Being relaxed and humane,
you will find happiness within yourself.
This is called setting in motion the vital force
so that your awareness and action become like Heaven.
It is ever so that man's life
is certain to depend on his being content.
Through sorrow he loses his guiding thread;
through anger he loses the beginnings.618
In sorrow and melancholy, joy and anger,
The Way can find no resting place.
Love and desires: quiet them!
Stupidity and confusion: rectify them!
Do not pull! Do not push!
Happiness will naturally be restored.
That the Way will naturally come
Is something you can count on and plan for.
If you are quiescent, you will obtain it.
If you move hastily, you will lose it.
In the heart the subtle breath of life
The spiritual force within the mind, sometimes arrives and sometimes departs.
So fine that nothing can exist within it;
so large that nothing can exist beyond it.619
The reason we lose it
is because haste is harmful.
When the mind is able to retain a state of quiescence,
The Way will become stable.
For the man who comprehends the Way
The lines [of his face] effuse [a sense of harmony], and his hair exudes it.620
Within his breast there is nothing corrupt.
Since he practices this method of moderating desires,
nothing ever causes him harm.

div.head:
16.2封禪第五十桓公既霸，
Duke Huan, having become lord protector,

p.seg: Fu Xi,
Shen Nong,
and Yan Di
did the same.623
Huang Di performed the Feng sacrifice at Mount Tai,
but the Shan sacrifice at Tingting.624
Zhuan Xu,
Di Ku,
Yao,
and Shun performed them at Mount Tai
and Yunyun,
while Yu performed the Feng at Mount Tai,
but the Shan at Kuaiji.625
Tang performed the two sacifices at Mount Tai
and Yunyun;
King Cheng of the Zhou performed them at Mount Tai
and Sheshou.626
All of these men had received the mandate of Heaven before performing the Feng and Shan sacrifices."
Duke Huan replied,
"In the north, I attacked the Mountain Rong627
and passed through Guzhu.628
In the west, I attacked the Greater Xia629
and crossed the Liusha.630
Having harnessed the horses and hitched the chariots together,
I ascended the Bier Mountains.631
In the south, I attacked as far as Shaoling
and climbed Mount Xionger
to gaze upon the Yangtze and Han river.632
I have convened three military
and six civil conferences,
nine times assembling the feudal lords
and thereby bringing unity and order to the entire realm.633
Among the feudal lords there is no one who dares oppose me.
How do I differ from those
who in the three periods of antiquity received the mandate of Heaven?"
Thereupon Guan Zhong, seeing that Duke Huan could not be dissuaded by such arguments,
set forth the details, saying,
"When the Feng and Shan sacrifices were performed in antiquity,
containers of panicled millet from Heshang
and spiked millet634 from Beili
were used as offerings.635
Special triple-ribbed reeds,
which grow between the Yangtze and the Huai rivers,
were used for mats.
Fish that have a pair of eyes on the same side of their head were brought from the Eastern Sea,
and birds that have only one wing each and must fly together were brought from the Western Sea.
Thereafter, over fifteen kinds of creatures came on their own accord without being summoned.
Now when the phoenix and unicorn have not appeared
and the good grains have not sprouted,
but various types of weeds flourish
and hawks and owls abound,
is it not unthinkable for you
to desire to perform the Feng and Shan sacrifices?"636
Thereupon the duke desisted.
"Expend effort on the land and act in accordance with the seasons.
Then the country will be certain to prosper,"
replied Guanzi.
Again the duke asked,
"I wish my actions to be of widespread humaneness and great righteousness
so that they will be of benefit to the realm.
Can this be done?"
"Punish the violent, prohibit wrongdoing,
reestablish states that have been destroyed, restore broken lines of succession,
and pardon the innocent.
Then your actions will be of widespread humaneness and great righteousness."
The duke said,637
"I have heard that
to punish the violent, prohibit wrongdoing, and pardon the innocent,
one must have the weapons to bring about victory in battle
and the stratagems for attacking and seizing an enemy.
Only then can one punish the violent, prohibit wrongdoing, and pardon the innocent.
"Select the bravest knights of the realm,
obtain its best materials,
and bring in its finest artisans, "
replied Guanzi.
"Then you will have the weapons to bring about victory."
"What are the stratagems for attacking and seizing an enemy?"
asked the duke.
"Destroy his equipment,
scatter his supplies,
and seize his food,"
said Guanzi.
"Then he will have no secure city walls."
"Given what you say," said the duke,
"how do I go about obtaining these knights?"
"Praise them and treat them politely,
give them rich rewards and do not cheat them.
Then the bravest knights of the realm will arrive."
"How do I obtain its finest materials?"
"For those things costing five, give six;
for those things costing nine, give ten,"
replied Guanzi.
"Do not set a fixed price."
"How do I bring in artisans?"
"If you treble their wages,
even a thousand li will not seem far to them."
Duke Huan said,
"Now that I have learned about weapons that will bring about victory
and stratagems for attacking and seizing,
may I ask how to know what successive steps to take
and how not to lose the advantage of terrain when setting the army in motion
and lauching surprise attacks on towns?"
"Use bribes to obtain information and study maps of enemy territory,"
replied Guanzi.
"How does one insure certain victory in the field?"
"Make use of deception."639
"I wish," said the duke,
"to kown everything about the realm. How do I go about it?"
"If one does not have a complete grasp of detail,
one will not be capable of understanding the realm, "
replied Guanzi.
The duke said,
"Is it not so that there are problems connected with defense, attack, and gathering intelligence from afar?"640
[Guanzi replied,]641 "Now if it is not certain that one's people will fight to the death,
one cannot entrust to them the difficulties of going out for defense or attack.
If it is not certain that they are trustworthy,
one cannot rely on them to know what lies beyond one's borders.
Now to rely on people who are not willing to fight to the death
while seeking to defend or attack,
and to rely on men who are not trustworthy
while seeking to know what lies beyond one's borders
帨hese are three manifestations of stupidity (san an) in regard to military affairs."642
"How does one make certain that one's people will fight to the death and be trustworthy?" [asked Duke Huan].643
"By understanding the three fundamentals (san ben)."
"What are the three fundamentals?"
"The first is called 'stabilizing influences' (gu),
the second is called "cases for social esteem' (zun),
the third is called 'hostages' (zhi)."
"What do you mean?"
asked the duke.
"The existence of their native city, father and mother, and ancestral tombs
are stabilizing influences,"
replied Guanzi.
"Their fields and houses, ranks and salaries
are the bases of their social esteem.
Their wives and children
can be hostages.
When these three fundamentals are all present,
you may expand your majestic power
and sharpen your demands,
but the people will certainly be willing to fight to the death and not deceive us."644
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi about maintaining good order among the people.
"Whoever shepherds the people,"
replied Guanzi,
"must always be aware of their suffering,
express his concern by being benevolent,
and avoid terrifying them with punishments
or restraining them with excessive force.
If you pay attention to these four,
it will be sufficient to maintain good order among the people."
Duke Huan said,
"I can see that this is good,
but why is my population so small?"645
"Now," replied Guan Zhong,
"having a small population is no disaster for country.
In ancient times, the son of Heaven occupied the central position
with a territory measuring only a thousand li square,
but as long as the four items I mentioned above were properly taken care of,
what worry had he about his population being small?
On the other hand, if whoever shepherds the people646 is unaware of their suffering,
the people will come to hate him.
If he does not express his concern by being benevolent,
his people will be very resentful.
If he terrifies them with punishments,
his people will become very deceitful.
If he restrains them with excessive force,
those who leave will never return
and those who would arrive will hesitate and not come forward.
Therefore when the sage kings shepherded their people,
they did not care whether they were numerous or not."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
"Let it be so.
However, how do we carry out such a policy?"
"Complete trustworthiness and extreme humaneness,
majestic deportment
and possessing rules of propriety
峷aying careful attention to these four is the means to carry it out,"
replied Guan Zhong.
"May I ask about this?"
xx
Guan Zhong replied,
"If you are trustworthy, [As for the trustworthy person... CH]
the people will believe in you.
If you are humane,
they will cherish you.
If you are majestic in your deportment,
xx
If you possess rules of propriety, [As for ritual propriety... CH]
they will praise you.
According to old saying,
to give up one's life rather than to violate a promise647
is what is meant by trustworthiness.
Never to inflict on others
what one would not wish for one's self
is what is meant by humaneness.648
To be firm within while outwardly correct
is what is meant by being majestic in one's deportment.
To be completely trustwothy and self-effacing
is what is meant by having rules of propriety."649
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
"When shepherding the people, what is the primary concern?"
replied Guanzi,
"Sometimes," "it is government;650
sometimes it is benevolence.651
During times when strong winds and violent rains
do not harm the people,
when dry spells and droughts do not bring calamities,
when the various streams flow smoothly,
the annual grain crop ripens,
grain is cheap,
birds and beasts are able to
share the food of men,
and people do not suffer from disease or pestilence
'At such times,
the people prosper and become arrogant.
He who shepherds the people should then amass large quantities of grain from the rich harvests
to fill the granaries
and prohibit the exploitaion of marsh lands.652
He653 should make administrative business his primary concern,
accompany it with punishments,
and use rules of propriety and music to warn his people
and to limit their excess.
This is what is meant by making government his primary concern.
During times when strong winds and violent rains harm the people,
when dry spells and droughts inflict calamities upon them,
when the annual grain crop does not ripen,
the harvest is extremely poor,
grain is expensive,
and the people suffer from disease and pestilence
'At such times,
the people are impoverished and exhausted.
He who shepherds the people should open the granaries, mountain forests, and marshlands in order to supply the people with their resources,
put his administrative business last,
and make the granting of mercy his primary concern
in order to limit the extent of their exhaustion.
This is what is meant by making benevolence his primary concern.
Amassing grain during years of bumper harvest
does not deprive the people of their wealth;
distributing it during years of exceedingly poor harvests
proves your benevolence.
To have enriched those on high while seeing to it that those below had enough
This was the highest accomplishment of the sage kings."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
Duke Huan questioned Guan Zhong, saying,
"When I wished to become lord protector,
it was the merit of you gentlemen
that made it possible.
Now I wish to become king.
Is it possible?"
"Your Grace should summon Shuya and ask him,"654
replied Guan Zhong.
When Bao Shu arriced,
the duke again posed his question,
but Bao Shu replied,
"Your Grace should summon Bin Xuwu and ask him."655
Bin Xuwu hurried forward,
and the duke again posed his question.
Bin Xuwu replied,
"The ancient kings
were princes who possessed great virtue,
while their ministers possessed somewhat less.
Nowadays, it is the ministers of princes who possess the greater virtue."
The duke shrank back and then solemnly left his position.
The three men, walking slowly, advanced toward the duke,
who said,
"The great king of antiquity was worthy;
so were King Ji,
and kings Wen
and Wu.656
King Wu attacked Yin and conquered it.657
Seven years later he died,
and the Duke of Zhou brilliantly assisted King Cheng in establishing good order throughout the realm.658
It was only then that the Zhou was able to extend its control to all within the four seas.
Now my sons are less worthy than I,
and I am less worthy than you gentlemen.
Looking at things from this point of view,
there is no doubt that I cannot become a king."
Duke Huan said,
"I wish to assert my supremacy over the people.
How do I do this?"
Guan Zhong replied,
"This is not the talk of a true prince.
Asserting one's supremacy over the people is easy,
but the way to accomplish this
is not the great way of ruling the realm.
If a prince merely wished to gain supremacy over his people,
he has his responsible officers post the details of criminal cases
and the rewards for exposing the guilty;
he has them conduct multiple investigations and carry out severe punishments.
In such a way, one may assert one's supremacy over the people.
Even though this is a way to assert one's supremacy over the people,
it is not the great way of ruling the realm.
Since it will cause the peole to stand in awe of Your Grace
but not look upon you as one of their own,
disasters may strike you quickly.
Even though you will be able to keep them from expressing their dissatisfaction,
men will hold back
and refuse to be any use.
What danger!
How great the peril to your country!"
Duke Huan went to examine the stables
and asked the functionary in charge (jiu li),
"What is the most difficult task in building a stables?"
The functionary in charge of the stables had not yet replied
when Guan Zhong answered,
"I was once a stable groom (yu ren).
The most difficult task involves the stalls for holding horses.
If you begin the enclosure with crooked lumber,
crooked lumber will require crooked lumber to make a fit.
Once you have begun with crooked lumber,
straight lumber cannot be used.
If you begin the enclosure with straight lumber,
straight lumber will require straight lumber to make a fit.
Once you have begun the enclosure with straight lumber,
crooked lumber cannot be used."
Duke Huan said to Guan Zhong,
"I want to attack those countries that are not submissive.
How do I go about it?"
"First," replied Guan Zhong,
"extend your love to everyone within your four boundaries.
Then afterward you can exact your hatred against those evil persons who live outside your borders.
First, stabilize the families of your minister of state (qing) and great officers (dafu).
Then afterward you may threaten neighboring enemy countries.
It was for this reason that the former kings were certain to set something up
before they proceeded to tear anything down.
It was also for this reason that they were certain to do something beneficial
before proceeding to do harm."
When Duke Huan mounted the throne
he ordered blood sacrifices performed at the altar to Land and thanks be given to the gods.
When the priest Fuyibi659 presented the sacrificial meat,
he intoned the blessing,
"Deliver us from the prince's pettiness as well as his tendency to be long on empty speech but short on real performance."
Highly displeased,
Duke Huan glared660 at the priest,
who then took up the wine and offered it in sacrifice, saying,
"Furthermore, let it be the same with the prince's pretentions to worthiness."
Duke Huan was very angry and was about to have the priest executed.
However, he stopped
before doing so in order to consult with Guan Zhong.
Guan Zhong thereupon realized Duke Huan's capacity for becoming a lord protector.
When Duke Huan was out riding his horse,
a tiger saw him from a distance and hid.
Duke Huan asded Guan Zhong about it, saying,
"Just now, when I was out riding on my horse,
a tiger saw me from a distance and did not dare approach.
What is the reason for this?"
"I think," replied Guan Zhong,
"that
you must have been riding a piebald661 horse and taking it easy
until you came face to face with the sun and then speeded up."
"That's right,"
said the Duke.
"This gave you the appearance of a bo,"
continued Guan Zhong.662
"It eats tigers and leopards.
That is why the tiger was afraid."663
Chu attacked Ju664
and Ju sent an emissary to seek help from Qi.
Duke Huan was about to assist Ju
when Guan Zhong said,
"Don't do it."
"Why not?"
asked the duke.
"When I spoke with the emissary from Ju,"
replied Guan Zhong,
"I insulted his prince three times,
but his face never changed color.
I then had an official hold back
three strings of cash from his ceremonial gift,
and this emissary was then willing to fight to the death.
The prince of Ju is a petty person.
You should not assist him."
Duke Huan, in the end, did not assist Ju, and Ju perished.
While on a spring excursion,
spending the third month sightseeing in the countryside,
Duke Huan asked,
"What thing in nature can be compared to the character of a virtuous prince?"
Xi Peng665 replied,
"Now unhusked grain (su)
lies within an armor coating.
In the middle it has a surrounding aril like a city wall,
and outside it has a swordlike awn.
Since it never dares to fend for itself alone,
it calls itself 'su'.666
In this way, it can be compared to the character of a virtuous prince."
Guan Zhong said,
"When it begins, a grain sprout;
how tender it is! how like a suckling babe.
As it grows strong,
how impressive it becomes, how like a knight.
When it matures,
how richly endowed667 it is!
how like a virtuous prince.
When the world has a such a prince, it is at peace;
when it does not, it is in peril.
Therefore mature grain is called he.668
In this way, it can be compared with the character of a virtuous prince."
Duke Huan said,
"Good!"
When Duke Huan was on his northern expedition against GuZhu,
he came to a sudden stop ten li
before reaching the Bier gorges.669
Staring straight ahead,
he grasped his bow as though about to shoot,
but having drawn the string, he dared not let fly.
Addressing his officials of the right and left, he said,
"Did you see that man in front of us?"
"No,"
they replied.
"Something must be wrong,"
continued the duke.
"I am confused.
Just now, I saw a man
who was only a foot tall, but who appeared completely human.
He was wearing a ceremonial cap,670 lifting his robe with his right hand,
and running quickly in front of my horse.
Something must be wrong.
I am confused.
How could there be such a person as this?"
Guan Zhong replied,
"I have heard that among the spirits who climb mountains there is a yuer.
He in only a foot tall but appears completely human.
When the prince who is to become lord protector to the king rises,
this spirit who climbs mountains appears.
Moreover, his running quickly in front of a horse
is to show the way.
His lifting his robe
indicates that there is water ahead.
That he does it with his right hand
indicates that to the right there is a ford."
When they reached the Bier gorges,
a guide
said,
"If you ford to the left,
the water will be up to your head.
If you ford to the right,
the water will only come up to your knees.
If you ford to the right,
everything will be fine."
Duke Huan immediately bowed before Guan Zhong's horse, saying,
"For a long time, Zhongfu,671 I have been at fault for failing to recognize that
your sagely wisdom was as great as this."
"I have heard,"
replied Guan Zhong,
"that sages know things before there is any sign of them.
Now I only knew this after a sign had already appeared.
Your servant is not a sage,
but only a person who is good at accepting their teachings."
Duke Huan sent Guan Zhong in search of Ning Qi.672
Ning Qi responded, saying,
"How vast!"673
Guan Zhong did not understand
and kept worrying about it right up until lunchtime.
"What are you worried about, sir?"
asked his maid servant.
"It is nothing a maid servant would know about,"
replied Guan Zhong.
"Sir," said the maid servant,
"you should not treat the young as being too young
or the lowly as being too low.
In ancient times, when the state of Wu and Han674 were at war,
it was a rule that those who had not yet lost their milk teeth could not enter the army.
Therefore the heir apparent of Han pulled out his own teeth
and subsequently performed
great service for his country.675
Bailixi
was a cowherd in Qin
before Duke Mu elevated him to be his prime minister.676
Therefore, the duke became lord protector over the other feudal lords.
In view of this,
how can you treat the lowly as being too low
or the young as being too young?"
"Right you are," said Guan Zhong.
"The duke sent me in search of Ning Qi,
but Ning Qi responded by saying, 飣ow vast!'
I do not understand."
The maid servant said,
"According to the Odes:677
Covering a vast expanse is water;
prolific are the fish.678
When I have no wife and family of my own,
how can you call upon me to stay?679
Isn't it that Master Ning wishes to get married?" [Guan]680 Zhong reported these words to Duke Huan.
Duke Huan and Guan Zhong, behind closed doors, made plans to attack Ju.6ī
However, before the attack could be launched,
news of the plan had already reached there.
Duke Huan was furious
and said to Guan Zhong,
Guan Zhong replied,
"That country must possess a sage."
"Right,"
said Duke Huan.
"Now among those who came to serve me on that day,6ǐ
there was a person who ate while maintaining his seat on the mat and kept looking up at us.6ì
It must have been he."
Thereupon he issued an order that that person should come against to serve him
and that there should be no substitutes.
In a little while
Dong Guoyou arrived.685
Duke Huan ordered the officer who was attending him to invite him to ascend the steps where the duke stood and,
sharing the same step with him,
asked,
"Were you the one who said that I was about to attack Ju?"
"Yes,
it was I."
Duke Huan said,
"I have never said anything in public about attacking Ju,
yet you said I would.
What is the explanation for this?"
"I have heard,"
replied Dong Guoyou,
"that a man of quality is good at formulating plans,
but a petty man is good at figuring them out.
I figured it out."
"How did you do it?"
asked Duke Huan.
"Joyous merriment
is the air of those playing bells and drums,"
replied Dong Guoyou.
"Deep stillness is the air of those wearing mourning garments.
Unrestrained excitement
and movement of hands, feet, and thumbs
are the air of those preparing for war.
That day, when I saw you two gentlemen on the dais
with your mouths open,
you were then speaking of Ju.686 When you raised your hands to point, it was in the direction of Ju.
Moreover, I noted that Ju
was the only one of the minor feudal lords who was not submissive.
For this reason,
I said you were going to attack Ju."
"Good!"
exclaimed Duke Huan.
"Taking small details and projecting them into an explanation"
such is the meaning of this.
Please be seated.
I wish to confer with you."
A certain guest sought an interview with Duke Huan of Qi
and requested that the he be employed in high office
with a salary of a thousand zhong of grain.687
Duke Huan told this to Guan Zhong,
who said,
"You should give it to him."
When the guest heard about this, he said,
"This humble servant will not serve you."
"Why not?"
asked the duke.
"I have heard," came the reply,
"that those whose hiring practices depend on the opinions of others,
will also use the opinions of others when it comes to firing.
I will not serve you."
Is careful in checking his financial accounts
so that his laws and orders will be stable.
Makes his rewards and punishments certain
so that his subjects will submit to his rules and procedures.
Does not use threats in dealing with his people but harmonizes them with his virtue,
so that they revert to being plain and simple [on their own].
Therefore688 the ruler is happy and safe,
his official functionaries are stern in their presence and strict in their actions,
and his people are simple and feel close to him.
His offices contain no depraved functionaries
and his court no wicked ministers.
His subordinates do not encroach upon his powers or struggle among themselves,
and in his generation no punishments are applied to the people.
The ruler who is overly kind: Grants lavish rewards and rich gifts, thereby exhausting his treasury.
Pardons wickedness and permits error, thereby harming his laws.
When his treasury is exhausted, such a ruler's political power delines.
When his laws are harmed, the gates to wickedness are opened.
Therefore it is said: "Too much of a good thing results in failure."
The ruler who is domineering: Indulges evil and violates the law, thereby harming himself.
Takes pleasure in deciding difficult matters on his own, thereby blocking out any enlightening point of view.
Engages in spying and enjoys petty inquisitions.
His undertakings lack constant standards, and his laws and orders are ineffectual.689
Unless he becomes aware of his faults,
his state will lose its authority.
The ruler who is reckless: His eyes infatuated with the five colors,
his ears absorbed in the five notes,
Of his surrounding neighbors, he takes no account,
of his inspectors general, he pays no heed.
Thus, his ministers and subordinate officials are unrestrained,
and the political power of the state is in a process of collapse.
Unless he becomes aware of his faults,
the evil consequences will be inflicted on himself.690
The ruler who belabors his people: Does not clearly distinguish responsibilities.
Superior and inferior are thus in conflict with each other
and minister and ruler act in similar fashion.
Punishments serve to increase his wealth;
wealth serves to intensify his oppression.691
If he does away with his punishments, there will be chaos;
if he persists in them, he will be in danger.692
Unless he becomes aware of his faults,693 for later genetations, what will be left?
The ruler who terrorizes his people: In joy and anger is unrestrained;
Punishes with great severity and grants no pardons.
Since his ministers and subordinate officials are terrified
but do not know what they have done wrong,
Everyone resorts to clever evasion.
Unless he becomes aware of his faults,
his laws and policies will daily decline in effectiveness,
and the state will lose its stability.
The ruler who is about to perish:694 Has no695 feeling for others, and by nature is suspicious.
Therefore, he does not trust his ministers and subordimate officials,
and exhausts himself managing his affairs.696
Since his affairs are numerous,
he becomes confused,
and since he is confused, irrespective of whether matters are pressing or not, he attempts to handle everything at once.
Unless he becomes aware of his faults,
whenever he sees something he does not like,
all his energy will have been completely dissipated, and he will be unable to do anything about it.697
Now, whether a person is well organized or not depends on his mind.
Whether a country continues to exist or not depends on its ruler.
Whether the empire is to be won or lost
stems from one person.
If the ruler favors essential production,
his people will like to clear weeds.698
If the ruler is fond of goods,
his people will engage in trade.
If the ruler is fond of palaces,
his workers and artisans will be very clever.
If the ruler is fond of the ornate and brightly colored,
his women workers will produce luxury goods.
The king of Chu was fond of small waists
and so beautiful women all cut down on their eating.
The king of Wu was fond of swordplay
and so the country's knights treated death lightly.
Dying and not eating
are things all the world hates.
So why do people do it?
It is because they are following the desires of their rulers.
How much more this becomes the case when amusements and music are involved.
Indeed, when men do not farm
and women do not weave,
but devote their labor and skill to useless things,
it is impossible
to expect the land to produce699
or the granaries to be full.
If the land does not produce,
the people will not have enough to eat.
If the people do not have enough to eat,
opposition will arise.
If opposition arises,
orders will not be carried out.
Thus, powerful enemies will launch their attacks,
and even though one may have skilled personnel, it will be impossible to survive.
How do we know this to be so?
In antiquity, Zhou700 was an example.
He execued the worthy and loyal,

On rocky mountains (lei shan)896with white-colored soil, it is 18 shi
or 126 chi
down to the water table,
but stones pressed together beneath the surface
xx
On mountains with some earth cover (tu shan),897 it is 19 shi
or 133 chi
down to the water table,
but limestone beneath the surface
makes it impossible to reach underground water.
On mountains with higher peaks and some soil cover (gao ling tu shan),898 it is 20 shi
or 140 chi
down to the water table.
At the top of some high mountains, there are areas known as "hanging springs."899
The land there is not dry.
Characteristic plants are madder (Rubia cordifolia)900 and wan.901
The characteristic tree is the larch (Larix Gmelinii).
Digging down two chi,
one reaches the water table.
At the top of some high mountains, there are areas known as902 "multiple peaks."903
Characteristic plants are the white aster (Aster fastigiatus)904 and clerodendron.905
The characteristic tree is willow.906
Digging down three chi,
one reaches the water table.907
At the top of some high mountains there are areas known as "spring-fed ravines."908
Characteristic plants are mountain angelica (Angelica polymorphai)909 and white pokeweed (Phytolacca pekinensis).910
The characteristic tree is the quaking aspen (Populus tremula).911
Digging down five chi,
one reaches the water table.
On mountains, in flat, thickly forested areas,912
Characteristic plants are stinkweed (Siegesbeckia pubescens) and common smartweed (Polygonum Hydropiper).913
The characteristic tree is the catalpa (Catalpa Bungei).914
Digging down two times seven or fourteen chi,
one reaches the water table.
On the lower slopes of mountains,915
characteristic plants are varieties of bindweed (Convolvulaceae)916 and wormwood or mugwort (artemisia).917
The characteristic tree is a thorn-elm (Hemiptelea Davidii).918
Digging down three times seven or twenty-one chi,
one reaches the water table.
With all plants and soils, it is the way
That each should have what is special to it.
Whether the elevation be high or low,
Each place has its characteristic plants and soils.
The lotus (Nelumbo nucifera)919 grows below the water chestnut (Trapa natans),
and then in ascending order come the bulrush (Scirpus lacustris),920
cattail (Typha latifolia),
wei
and huan reeds,921
a variety of wormwood or mugwort (Artemisia),
broom plant (Kochia Scoparia or trichsphylla),
xx
a dryland sedge (Scirpus),922
lion's tail (Leonurus sibiricus),923
and floss grass (Imperata cylindrica or arundinacea).
All plants
may be divided into these twelve categories,
And each category has plants that belong to it.
The soil of the nine regions (zhou)
may be divided into ninety different types.
Each soil has its unchanging characteristics,
but there are gradations in types.
Of all the various soils,
the five types of su soils are definitely the best.924
Su soils
may be red, green, white, black, or yellow,
But each manifests the group's special qualities.
Their chief characteristic is that
when wet, they are not sticky,
when dry they are not totally lacking in moisture.925
They will not mire cart wheels
nor dirty hands and feet.
Their characteristic grains926 are coarse and fine varieties of glutinous spiked millet (Setaria italica)927
that have light green stalks and spikes.
Whether on hills or mountains,
Whether on the banks of rivers or broad plains,
The five su soils
are fully suitable for
xx
Numerous other trees, including the elm (Ulmus campestris) and weeping willow (Salix babylonica),
yan929 and mulberry (Morus alba),
Silkworm thorn (Cudrania triloba) and serrated oak (Quercus serrata),
sophora (Sophora japonica) and quaking aspen (Populus tremula),
Grow in profusion, quickly reach maturity,
xx
Marshes here are filled with fish,
and pastures are suitable for cattle and sheep.
Both the flatland and the hillsides of this soil area
are suitable for different varieties of bamboo, As well as the jujube (Zizyphus vulgaris)930 and catalpa (Captalpa Kaempferi),931 big-leaf oak (Quercus glandulifera) and tan.932
Several933 fragrant plants also inhabit the area:
Chinese iris (Iris Pallasii)934 angelica (Angelica anomala),
mi wu, Chinese pepper (Zanthoxylum alatum), and forsythia (Forsythia suspensa).
The effect of these fragrant plants is to
decrease illness and slow down the process of aging.
Both men and women feel well,
And the people in general are hardworking and skillful.
The underground water here is yellowish in color,
and its men are even tempered and generous.935
The five su soils,
when dry are never hard;
When wet, they do not erode away.
No matter whether high or low, They preserve their moisture content and resist erosion.
This is what is meant by su soils.
Soils ranked below the su are called the five wu.936
The wu soils may be
red, green, yellow, white, or black.
Each of these five types of wu soils differs in what it does best.
Their chief characteristic is that
they are loose and porous937 and laced with small holes,
In which earthworms find space to live.938
That it is porous, but does not turn white
Is because beneath the surface the soil is moist.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of glutinous panicled millet (Panicum miliaceum)939
that have red stalks and dark green940 panicles,
and grow tall like bitter bamboo (Phyllostachys bambusoides).941
Whether on low hills or mountains,
high hills or mountainous ridges,
Whether in some secluded corner or on the sunny side of some hill,
Everywhere, whether to the left or to the right,
The five wu soils are suitable for numerous trees:
The tong (Paulownia tomentosa) and Chinese oak (Quercus serrata, var., chinensis), Asiatic juneberry (Amelanchier asiatica),942 fragrant cedar (Cedrela sinensis), and white catalpa.943
The dark purple plum (Prunus Mume), apricot (Prunus Armeniaca),
peach (Prunus Persica), and red plum (Prunus communis),
Give forth abundant fruit and their trunks grow tall.
xx
Numerous other trees, including the jujube (Zizyphus vulgaris) and wild pear (Pyrus betuliaefolia),944
The sophora (Sophora japonica) and quaking aspen (Populus tremula),
The elm (Ulmus campestris) and mulberry (Morus alba),
The purple willow (Salix purpurea)945 and sweet oak (Quercus glauca),946
Quickly reach maturity
and have limbs that are straight and long.
In shady areas grow pears (Pyrus sp.)947 and hawthorns (Crataegus cuneata);948
In sunny areas949 may be planted various species of hemp (Cannabis sativa).950
This is true no matter whether the land be hihg or low,
And irrespective of the lacale.
Coarse varieties of hemp grow tall like bitter bamboo (Phyllostachys bambusoides) or wei reeds (Phragmites communis).
They are large, tall and of superb quality.951
Fine varieties grow like huan reeds (Phragmites communis)952 and horseweed (Erigeron canadensis).
In lively fashion, they compete with one another in reaching upward.953
The large have no knots [to create imperfections];
the small are easy to process.
Their fibers may be collected and stored
like skeins of silk that have been softened by boiling.
Several fragrant plants also inhabit the entire area:
forsythia,954 yu,955 mi wu,956
gao ben (Nothosmyrnium japonicum),957 and angelica (Angelica anomala).
Marshes here are filled with fish,
xx
The undergroud water is a light clear green in color,958
And the men are firm and strong,
Seldom having itchy sores
and never afflicted with headaches or dizziness.
The five wu soils
when dry are never encrusted with salt.959
When wet, they do not erode.960
No matter whether high or low, They preserve their moisture content and resist erosion.
This is what is meant by wu soils.
Soils ranked below the wu are called the five wei.961
The five types of wei soils
appear in mixtures of the five colors,
And each manifests different special qualities.
Their chief characteristic is that
they neither harden to form clods nor disintegrate to become dust.
They have a greenish tinge, are porous, and lichenous.962
Their characteristic grains are coarse
and fine varieties of a red glutinous panicled millet (Panicum miliaceum)963
xx
Whether on mountains ridges or high hills,
Whether on the banks of rivers or broad plains,
Whether on low hills or mountains,
The five wei soils are all suitable for various varieties of bamboo,

The jujube (Zizyphus vulgaris), catalpa (Catalpa Kaempferi), big-leaf oak (Quercus glandulifera), and tan,965 Elm (Ulmus campestris),966 peach (Prunus Persica), weeping willow (Salix babylonica), and Persian lilac (Melia Azedarach).
xx
In shallow depressions at the base of mountains
grow prince's feather (Polygonum orientale) and Chinese mustard (Brassica juncea).967
Numerous trees grow extremely well here;
their branches become long and they quickly reach maturity.
The mulberry (Morus alba), pine (Pinus),
purple willow (Salix purpurea),968 rong,969
And various other trees are all included in this.
Here also,970
numerous medicinal plants and trees easily grow,
Including ginger (Zingiber officinale) and balloonflower root (Platycodon grandiflorum),971
Birthwort (Aristolochia sieboldi) and herb paris (Paris tetraphylla).
On mountain foothills,972
Grow stinking elms (Ulmus macrocarpa) and thorn-elms (Hemiptelea Davidii).
On mountains' lower half,973
Grow woodberry (Rubus palmatus) and purple aster (Aster tatricus).
On higher mountainsides,
Here grows yellow fritillary (Fritillaria verticillata);974
There grows sweet flag (Acorus Calamus).
xx
Numerous medicinal plants are also easily gathered
so that people may ward off misfortune.
In its woodlands and mountain forests,
Are found sophora (Sophora japonica) and white maple (Acer sp.),975
Serrated oak (Quercus serrata) and paper mulberry (Broussonetia papyrifeta).
Here numerous trees grow extremely well,
and birds and animals readily congregate,
Including both the mi and biao976
as well as large numbers of the common sika deer (Cervus sika).
The undergroud water here is greenish black in color,
The men are lively and upright,
Handle matters in simple fashion, and eat little.
No matter whether high or low, [These five soils] preserve their moisture content and resist erosion.
This is what is meant by wei soils.
Soils ranked below the wu are called the five yin.977
The chief characteristic of the five yin is that
they are a black soil that produces black lichens.
It has a greenish tinge, is porous,978 fertile,
xx
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of leige rice980
that have red stalks and yellow panicles with black spots,9ī
and leaves like those of the wan.9í
Whether it be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
such a soil is 20 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
This is what is meant by ying soils.
Soils ranked below the yin are called the five rang.9ǐ
The chief characteristic of the five rang is that
they are powdery like starch and damp.9ì
Their characteristic grains are coarse
and fine varieties of wet chang rice985
that have red stalks and yellow panicles with black spots.986
They are capable of withstanding flood and drought
and may be planted anywhere.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
rang soils are 20 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
This is what is meant by rang soils.
Soils ranked below rang are called the five fu.987
The chief characteristic of the five fu is that
they consist of loose particles like kernels of grain,
but since they retain their moisture
they do not scatter or crack.
There characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of yinren millet,988
the leaves of which grow long like those of the huan reed (Phragmites communis)989
and are as luxuriant as the hair on a fox.
Their stalks may be either yellow or black; their panicles are black.
They are large grained
xx
The first group in the intermediate grade of soils is called the five ju.991
The chief characteristic of the five ju is that
they are light like jian loess,992
but they have a high moisture content and resist [wind] erosion.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of nonglutinous spiked millet993
that have red stalks and yellow spikes with black spots.994
They are able to withstand flood and drought
and are small-grained like mi.995
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
ju soils are 30 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below ju are called the five lu.996
The chief characteristic of the five lu is that
they are hard and firm.
Their characteristic grains are coarse
and fine varieties of Handan rice997
that have stalks and leaves like fuxun998
and large grains.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
xx
Soils ranked below lu are called the five jian.999
The chief characteristic of the five jian is that
they are powdery like grain dust and covered with a fragile crust.1000
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of li millet1001
that have green stalks and yellow panicles (spikes?).
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
jian soils are 30 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below jian are called the five piao.1002
The chief characteristic of the five piao is that
they are like a powder used in paint that is white in color.1003
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of ju millet1004
that have black stalks and green panicles.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
piao soils are 40 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below piao are called the five sha.1005
The chief characteristic of the five sha is that
they are grainy like rice grits,1006 containing fine dust and coarse grains.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of pei millet1007
that have white stalks and green panicles with red spots.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
sha soils are 40 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below sha are called the five ge.1008
The chief characteristic of the five ge is that
they are as rocky as a stone pile
and unable to withstand flood or drought.
Their characteristic grains are coarse
and fine varieties of qiuqi millet1009 that has black stalks and black panicles.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
ge soils are 40 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
These thirty types of intermediate grade soils altogether
produce twelve different types of grain.1010
The first group of lower-grade soils is called the five you.1011
The chief characteristic of the five you is that they smell like manure.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of hua millet1012
that have white stalks and black panicles.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
you soils are 50 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below you are called the five zhuang.1013
The chief characteristic of the five zhuang is that they are the color of a rat's liver.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties1014 of green liang millet1015
that have black stalks and black panicles.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
xx
Soils ranked below zhuang are called the five zhi.1016
The chief characteristic of the five zhi is that
[when wet], they may become completely saturated and disintegrate,
or [when dry], they may crack and lose their vitality.1017
Their characteristic grains are yanshan ricē018
with black kernels and zhufu ricē019 with yellow kernels.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
xx
Soils ranked below the zhi are called the five que.1020
The chief characteristic of the five que is that they are infertile
and incapable of withstanding flood or drought.
Their characteristic grains are coarse and fine varieties of soybeans (Soja hispida),1021
which produce many white beans.
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
que soils are 60 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below the que are called the five xi.1022
The chief characteristic of the five xi is that
they are firm but not completely hard.
Their characteristic grains are leng rice,1023 hei e, and ma fu.1024
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
xi soils are 70 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
Soils ranked below the xi are called the five jie.1025
The chief characteristic of the five jie is that
they are extremely salty and bitter.
As a soil type, they rank at the very bottom.
Their characteristic grains is a long, narrow variety of white rice.1026
Whether they be used for animal husbandry, agriculture, horticulture, or forestry,
jie soils are 70 percent less productive than the three (su, wu, and wei) soils.
These thirty types of lower-grade soils altogether
produce twelve different types of grain,
and the entire total of ninety types
[in all three grades] of soil produce thirty-six types of grain.
Observing constant standards whether abroad or at home,
they are certain to seek out those who are virtuous.
Their features being well composed,
their inner thoughts are certain to be exemplary in their correctness.
Though they awaken early and go to bed late,
their dress is certain to be tidy.
Mornings being devoted to enhancing their learning and evenings to practicing what they have learned,
they are ever cautious of doing anything wrong.1027
Being ever diligent in concentrating on these things:
such are the standards for study.
Young students in rendering service
are late to bed and early to rise.
When sweeping the floor in front of the teaching mat and washing their hands and rinsing their mouths,
they conduct themselves in a respectful manner.1028
Once they have finished dressing and prepared the washbasin for the teacher,
he also rises.
When he has completed his toilet, the students remove the basin,
sprinkle and sweep the floor, and adjust the teacher's mat.
The teacher then seats himself,
and the students in going out or coming in
are as respectful as if they were greeting guests.
They sit in a dignified manner facing the master,
their features composed and never changing.
For receiving instruction, there are giudelines:
The eldest student must come first.
The first time around, it is like this,
but thereafter it is not.
The first time students recite their lessons, they must stand,
but thereafter they do not.1029
If a student arrives late,
his fellow students on either side will stand [so he may find a seat].
Should there appear a guest,
A student will immediately arise.
Since a guest cannot be denied,
The student will welcome him and hurry to carry out his wishes,
Rushing to the teacher for instruction.
Even though the person the guest seeks is not present,
the student will still report back to him.
He then returns to his seat and resumes his studies.1030
If a student has a question,
He will raise his hand to ask it.
In1031 his every word and action, the student takes moderation as his guide. In the past, those who would flourish were certain to begin like this.
At mealtimes,
when the teacher is about to eat,
a student prepares food for him.
Having pulled up his sleeves, washed his hands, and rinsed his mouth,
the server then kneels down to present the food.
When the sauces, grain, and various dishes are set forth,
it must be done in an orderly fashion.
Vegetable stews1032 are served before
dishes of fowl, meat, fish, or turtle.
Both the stews and sliced meat dishes are placed in the middle but kept separate.1033
Meat dishes having been placed in front of the sauces,
the entire setting forms a square.
The grain1034 is served last;
on the left is the wine, on the right is jiang water.1035
Having reported that everything is ready, the student withdraws and,
cupping his hands before him in obeisance, stands to one side.
[The normal meal consists of] three servings of grain to which soup is added twice.1036
The student holds in his left hand a pottery serving dish,
in his right chopsticks or a ladle.
He refills the various dishes in order
as soon as he sees they are becoming empty.1037
If two dishes become empty at the same time, he refills them in the order they were originally served.1038
Having refilled all the dishes, he begins the cycle again.
Since his serving implement has a foot-long handle,
such are the guidelines for making refills.
When the teacher has finished eating,
the student clears everything away,
And hastens to bring in [a basin for the teacher] to rinse his mouth,
sweeps the floor in front of the mat, and gathers1039 together the sacrificial utensils.1040
Once the teacher gives the order,
the students then begin their meal.
They arrange themselves properly according to age
and are certain to sit at the very front of the mat.1041
Grain must be picked up and eaten with the fingers,1042
but stews are not eaten with the hands.
It is permissble for them to rest [their hands] on their knees,
xx
Having eaten to full,
they should cup their hands and touch the edges of their mouths [to see if any food particles remain there],
Shake their skirts [to get rid of any food crumbs], brush them off the mat,1043
and, having completed their meal, rise from their places.
Gathering up their clothing,
they step down from the mat and turn to face it.
Each person then clears away the remains of his food
as though he were a guest.1044
Having cleared the food, they put away the utensils,
And then return to their positions.1045
When sweeping the floor in front of the teaching mat, students should use the following method:
They should fill a basin with water
and roll up their sleeves1046 to the elbow.
In a large hall, they may sprinkle the water by tossing it widely about;
in a small room they should sprinkle by taking only a little in their hands.
When the dustpan is held, the tongue should be pointed toward the sweeper;1047
in the middle is placed the broom.1048
The sweeper, on entering the door, stands for a while
to make sure his demeanor is without fault.
He holds the broom in his hand and lowers the dustpan,
leaning it against the doorjamb.
For sweeping in front of the teaching mat, there are guidelines:
The sweeper must begin with the southwest corner,
