Moving back and forth with his back bent in the shape of a qing,
He makes certain that he does not knock into anything.
From the front of the room, he works backward,
Collecting the drit just inside the door.
Then, squatting down, he gathers up the dirt by pushing it into the dustpan with his hand.
He points the tongue of the dustpan toward himself [???]
and places the broom across it.
Should the teacher rise [from his place on the mat],
the sweeper will straighten up and excuse himself.
Then, after squatting down to grasp [the dustpan and broom], he reassumes a standing position
and proceeds to remove them.
Having finished with his sweeping, the sweeper then returns to his position
this all being in accord with the object of his studies.
During the evening meal, the students repeat the morning's ritual.
At dusk they light the torches
and then sit in the corners of the room holding them.
The mothed for stocking the supply of faggots
is to lay them crosswise to the [torch holder's] sitting position.
When the torch has burned down to an appropriate length,
he lights a new one
by placing it at right angles to the old one like a carpenter's square.
He leaves a faggot's width between them,
the one that is already burning being just below the one being lit.1049
At the same time he holds up a basin [to catch falling] embers.
Then, with his right hand grasping the old torch,
He trims1050 the burning end with his left,
but should any embers be about to drop,1051 another student will replace him in holding the torch.
When exchanging seats, students must not turn their back on those who hold positions of honor.
Subsequently, the burned ends are taken out
and discarded.
When the teacher is about to retire,
the students all stand.
They respectfully present him with his pillow and mat
and ask him where he would like to place his feet.1052
The first time they arrange his sleeping mat, they request this information,
but once the pattern has been eatablished, they do not.1053
After the teacher has retired,
each student seeks out his friends,
Dissecting and polishing,
Each one strengthens his arguments.
The day's routine having been completed, the next day it begins anew.
Such are the guidelines for students.

div.head: 21.1立政九敗解第六十五管子解三。
21.4巨乘馬第六十八管子輕重一。

p.seg: "What do you mean by saying that it lies
with its administrative orders?"
"A single peasant's capacity to cultivate land
is limited to one hundred mu,1054
and his spring work must be completed within twenty-five days."
"What do you mean by saying that it must be completed in twenty-five days?"
"The spring thaw in sunny areas occurs sixty days after the winter solstice;
in shady areas it is seventy-five days.1055
Once the thaw is complete in shady areas, millet is planted.1056
Since it can no longer be planted after one hundred days,
spring work must be completed within twenty-five days and that is all.
Now, you, My Lord, are erecting a tower at Fu,1057
and the masses from the 而ve directions1058 are all working on it.
Since you have continued this work on past the spring without stopping
and the people have been deprived of their twenty-five days of work,
land within the five directions has been neglected and abandoned.
For each man conscripted to perform government service,
the yield from a hundred mu will not be forthcoming.
For each ten men
it will be a thousand mu;
for each hundred,
it will be ten thousand;
and for each thousand men conscripted for government service,
the yield of a hundred thousand mu will not be forthcoming.
"This spring, you have already lost the twenty-five days for planting millet,
and if you still raise labor for this summer,
you will have lost this spring's work on the land
and this summer's sprouting of crops.
If you continue to conscript labor this fall without stop,
this will be a multiple loss in respect to harvesting grain and cultivating land.
"When the time for harvesting grain is lost,
but your officials1059 continue to levy special taxes1060 without end,
you will have confiscated nine-tenths1061
of the people's grain.
If these officials then seek additional wealth,
it will give rise to robbery and violence
and a multiplicity of punishments.
Should this then be followed by further violence,
it will become a civil war."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
Guanzi then continued:1062 "All this is because you have not yet made full use of the art1063 of planned fiscal management.
Those who became kings did not deprive the people of their seasonal work.
Therefore the five grains flourished,
and since the five grains flourished,
members of the gentry made light of salaries,
and the people ignored rewards.
Those who are good at running their countries see to it
that peasants plow when the weather is still cold, and weed when it is hot,1064
and that the fruits of their labor go to the ruler on high.
They see to it that women are diligent in performing fine and delicate work,
and that the textiles they produce go to public storehouses.1065
This is not something to create resentment among the people
or ruin their aspirations,
it is the inevitable result of planning based on
the raising and lowering of prices."
"What is to be done about it?"
asked Duke Huan.
"The state of Yū066 mastered the art of planned fiscal management,"
replied Guanzi.
"What do you mean by the art of planned fiscal management?"
"Provide a plan for peasants working one hundred mu that states:
"As a rule, twenty-five days will be allotted to you for your spring work
and money will be lent to you.'
When the autumn harvest1067 rolls around and the grain has become completely ripe,
its price within the country will drop by half.
Then you should announce to the peasants:
"Your loan shall be repaid
in the form of grain, which shall be stored in the subdistricts (zhou) and villages (li).'
When the amount of grain in state hands comes to exceed 50 percent,
its value will increase twenty times.
You should then inform the various of officials in the outer districts (xian), villages, and towns (yi) both far and near that they shall all provide your government with implements and weapons.1068
Tell them that
since the state lacks money,
it will use grain of equal value to pay for them.
The official pricē069 of state grain
will consistently produce a profit of 90 percent,
and by returning grain in payment for implements and weapons,
weapons and implements for the state will all be supplied,
with no need to impose special taxes on the people.
xx

div.head: 21.5乘馬數第六十九管子輕重二。

p.seg: "Issue orders setting a standard price [for grain]1072
and main者in control over land utilization
and policies affecting people.1073
In this way opening and closing tha gates to wealth will lie entirely in the hands of the ruler on high,
and there will be no need to seek it directly from the people.
"The state of a lord protector1074 can only control half its wealth with the ruler
and1075 his subjects maneuvering back and forth in respect to the remaining half in order to satistfy their needs.
Since a state that adheres to the way of a true king controls its wealth from the beginning,
if its needs are deficient by one part,
it will add one;
if it is deficient by two,
parts it will add two,
and so on up to ten.
"Since its prince controls the raising and lowering of grain prices,
from each year's harvest he can set aside in storage 30 percent of the crop.
In ten years, then, he will have a three-year surplus.
Then, if there is a year of severe droughts or floods
and the people lose their primary source of income,
he builds palaces and pavilions,
thereby providing employment for those households so poor that they have neither a dog in front nor a pig behind.
Thus, hisbuilding of palaces
and pavilions is not to gratify his pleasure,
but to maintain equilibrium in the economic policies of the state.
"Now, however, when it comes to the prince who fails to institute planned fiscal management,
he is oblivious to the beginning and end of seasons
and launches projects,
mobilizes the masses,
and erects palaces and pavilions spring and fall, summer and winter.
His people lose their primary sources of income,
but he is unaware of having ruined his plans for spring
and that the failure of his plans for summer and fall has become inevitable.
xx
Fierce and resolute men will become exceedingly violent,
while people who are poor and sick
become beggars. Should the prince implement laws to restrain them,
the people may be punished and executed, but they will not submit to his government on high.
Such are the results of failure in the art of planned fiscal management.
"The standard prices for commodities associated with fiscal management
should be the same throughout the empire.
If your standard price is cheaper (qing) than that of others, your goods flow abroad.
If it is more expensive (zhong), goods will be dumped on you.
This being the case, the goods of rival states will flow back and forth,
and experts who have mastered these fluctuations in price (qing zhong) will compete with each other for profit.
When it comes to the state that adheres to the way of a true king,
the prince controls the flow of goods and puts a stop to this."
"What do you mean by saying 凐e controls the flow of goods'?"
said Duke Huan.
"From one man's plowing, five people may eat,"
replied Guanzi.
"Or it may be only four people,
three people,
or even just two,
but in each case the amount of effort expended in working the land is the same.
However, when work in the fields and policies affecting prices support each other,
it means that the state's economic policies can maintain control over seasonal activities.1077
Should the prince fail to maintain control over policies affecting prices,
the people will control them from below.
When this happens, the economic policies of the state become meaningless."
"Is this all there is
to the art of fiscal management?" asked Duke Huan.
"Establish prices
for textiles and other commodities.
The price of commodities will rise or fall
along with the value of money,
and it is grain alone that will determine whether they are expensive or cheap."
"What do you mean that 偑rain alone will determine whether things are expensive or cheap'?"
"When grain is expensive, all other things are cheap;
when grain is cheap, all other things are expensive."
"How does one further pursue the art of planned fiscal management?"
asked Duke Huan.
"In the commanderies (jun) and prefectures (xian),
levy a specific amount of tax on first-class land,
another specific amount
on intermediate-class land,
and a third specific amount
on lower-class land.
Then, having fixed your tax rates on the basis of the relative fertility of their soils,
people will not move away.
You will then have provided relief for the poor, and assisted those who do not have enough,
and your subjects below will be happy with their ruler on high.
All this is because you will have taken the richness of first-class soils
to make up for the deficiencies of those in the lowest class.
If you are able to take charge of the four seasons,
control the opening and closing of gates to wealth,
and your people do not move away,
it will provide a stability similar to placing a square object on the ground.
This is what is meant by the art of planned financial management."
Sacrificial rites involving dishes and platters must entail the use of sacrificial animals.
If the Greater Lao sacrifice of the feudal lords
and the Lesser Lao sacrifice of the great officers
fail to do this,
the six domestic animals will not proliferate.1079
If pavilions are not lofty
and palaces elegant,
various kinds of woods will not be widely used.'
What do you think of this statement?"
"It is not the right method,"
said Guanzi.
"What do you mean 剫t is not the right method'?"
"This is a method suitable for places where the amount of territory to be held by each rank is set:
The amount controlled by the son of Heaven is a thousand li square,
while that of the ordinary feudal lords is a hundred li square.
Along the seacoast, the amount controlled by a viscount (zi) is seventy li square,
and that of a baron (nan) is fifty.
These all work together like the chest and arms.
Therefore stabilizing the pressure of government demands and coping with surpluses and shortages
may be handled completely by the people below
and not become the concern of the prince.
However, where the territory is small but the prince wishes tō080 compete with larger states,
the peasant must plow when it is still cold and weed when it is hot,
but the fruits of his labor wil go to the government.
Women must be diligent in spinning and weaving,
but the results of their work will go to public storehouses.10ī
This is not done to create resentment among the people
or ruin their aspirations
but is due to the fact that unless he possesses accumulated reserves,
the prince will have nothing with which to employ men.
Furthermore, unless he possesses accumulated wealth,
he will have nothing with which to encourage his subordinates.
Great Extravagance's plan
cannot be used in a country that is facing danger."
"Good!"
Said Duke Huan.
Duke Huan again questioned Guanzi, saying,
"Idle Fields (Yitian) said to me,
偲hose who are skillful can make use of the resources that do not belong to them
and employ men other than their own.10í
Why not rely on the help of the feudal lords in controlling the empire'?"
Guanzi replied,
"What Idle Fields says is wrong.
When it comes to those who are good at running their countries:
Their land having been opened for culrivation,
Their people settle down.
Their granaries being full,
Their people know propriety and moderation.10ǐ
Moreover, if a country lacks public stores of grain, it will be besieged.
If its city walls are weak,10ì they will be penetrated.
Indeed, unless one stabilizes the internal situation it is impossible to retain control of the empire.
What Idle Fields says is wrong."
Guanzi then continued, saying,
"If every year one-tenth of the harvest is stored away,
in ten year there will be a full year of reserves.
If every year two-tenths of the harvest is stored away,
in five years there will be a full year of reserves.
If half of the year's grain is taken over by the state
and vegetables1085 are gathered by the people to make up for this,
then half of the grain will be in the hands of the government.
"Therefore take careful note of the harvest and store up grain accordingly.
Over a period of time, accumulate stores
so that the state will have ten years of reserves.1086
Prosperity will then vanquish poverty,
bravery will vanquish cowardice,
wisdom will vanquish stupidity,
the subtle will vanquish the crude,
those having a sense of duty will vanquish those who do not,
and trained knights will vanquish the untrained hordes who are forced to fight.
With all1087 these victories in hand,
you will sally forth like the wind and rain
and move like thunder.
Since you will be able to go and come freely,
no one will be able to resist you.1088
There is no need to wait upon allies.
Therefore what Idle Fields says is wrong."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
"I wish to place a special tax on the six domestic animals."
"This will lead to killing the living."
"I wish to place a special tax on men.
What about that?"
"That will lead to their concealing their true numbers."1089
"Such being the case," Duke Huan continued,
"How am I to run the country?"
Guanzi replied,
"Only by managing the mountains and seas."
"What do you mean by 勖anaging the mountains and seas'?"
"The state of a king who takes advantage of the sea
pays very careful attention to plans for collecting revenue on salt."
"What do you mean by 厜lans for collecting revenue on salt'?"
"In a household of ten persons,"
responded Guanzi,
"ten people will eat salt;
in a household of a hundred persons,
a hundred will eat salt.
Each month an adult male will consume five and a third1090 sheng of salt.1091
An adult female will consume three and a third sheng,
and a child, two and a third sheng.1092
These are general figures.
One hundred sheng of salt equals one fu.1093
If you were to order1094 the price of salt to be increased half a copper cash,
for each fu this would be fifty cash.
If you were to increase it by one cash,
for each fu it would be a hundred cash.
If you were to increase it by two cash,
for each fu it would be two hundred cash.
For each zhong1095 it would be two thousand cash,
for ten ten zhong it would be twenty thousand,
for one hundred zhong two hundred thousand,
and for a thousand zhong, it would be two million.
In a country of ten thousand chariots,1096
the total population will number ten million.
By combining these figures,
one arrives at an estimated income of two million cash per day.1097
In ten days it will amount to twenty million cash,
and in one month to sixty million.
"In a country of ten thousand chariots,
men who could be subjected to special tax levies will number one million.1098
If each month each of these men pays a special tax of thirty cash,
it will only amount to thirty million cash.
Now, without placing a special tax on either adults or children,
we may have sixty million cash, the tax income of two such countries.
If you, my lord, were to issue an order stating,
'I am going to impose a special tax on all adults and children,'
it would give rise to great yelling and screaming.
But now supposing you issue orders adopting the salt plan,
then even if the amount reverting to your government were a hundred times this,
men would have no way to avoid it.
Such would be the inevitable results.1099
"Now, the method relevant to the officials in charge of iron production1100 is as follows:
Each woman must have a needle and scissors
before she can carry on her work.
Each person who cultivates the soil must have a digging fork, a plow, and a hoe
before he can carry on his work.
Each person who builds and maintains hand carts and small and large horse-drawn wagons must have an axe, a saw, an awl, and a chisel
before he can carry on his work.
Without such tools,
no one in the world can be successful.
"Now if you were to increase the price of a needle by one cash,
with thirth needles it would equal the amount of a special tax on one individual.1101
Should you increase the price of scissors by six cash,
five times six being thirty,
with five scissors it would equal the amount of a special tax on one individual.
Should you increase the price of iron for a plow by ten cash,
with three plows it would equal the amount of a special tax on one individual.
The relative value (qing zhong) of the other tools should all be adjusted accordingly.
Then, as a consequence, there will be no one who as much as raises a hand to do his work
who will not be subject to this special tax."
Duke Huan said,
"Is it the case, then, that a state that lacks mountains and seas cannot achieve kingship?"
"It can rely on the mountains and seas of otheres and avail itself of them.
Command those states that have a seacoast
to sell salt to our country.
For every fu worth fifty cash that we receive,
the office in charge will sell it for a hundred.
Even though we will have taken no part in the original production,
we can import the production of others
and adjust the price.
Such is the method of using the resources of others."
The five grains and ricē105
are the people's Masters of Destiny;1106
gold and copper knife money
are their mediums of exchage.
Therefore those who are skilled in govenment manage mediums of exchage
in order to control the Masters of Destiny.
In such a way the strength of the people may be tapped and utilized to the full.
Now people trust those who are concerned about them1107 and will die for profit.
Within the four seas, it is always thus.
When the people have things given to them, they become happy,
but when things are taken away, they become angry.
Such is the nature of people.
Knowing this to be so,
the former kings made a display of giving
while concealing the nature of their taking away.
As a result, it became possible for the people's affection to extend to the ruler on high.
The imposition of special levies and taxes
is a way to gain one's desires through force.
Land rents and regular commercial taxes
are the way to make requests based on prior calculations.
Those princes who became kings and lord protectors
abandoned the process of making requests
based on prior calculations.
Therefore the world was happy to follow them.
If benefits emerge from a single outles,
the state will have no equal.
If they emerge from two outlets,
its troops will be halfhearted1108 in their actions.1109
If they emerge from three outlets,
it will not be able to mobilize an army.
If they emerge from four outlets,
the state will be lost.
Knowing this to be so,
the former kings prevented their people from having surpluses
and restricted their opportunities for profit.
Consequently, giving
and taking away,
impoverishing
and enriching all lay in the hands of the princes.
As a result, the people elevated the ruler on high to the level of the sun and moon
and loved their prince as their father and mother.
All those who would rule states
but do not understand qing zhong economic policies
will be unable to establish an encompassing framework1110 to control their people.
Nor will they be able to regulate their people's profits
or even discuss the establishment of a "great government."1111
Under such circumstances a country of ten thousand chariots
will have traders who have accumulated ten thousand catties of gold
while a country of a thousand chariots
will have traders who have accumulated a thousand.1112
When this is the case, what does it mean?
It means that if a country lets huge amounts of profit slip away,
ministers will not be completely loyal,
and knights will not be completely willing to fight to the death.
As the harvest is bad or good,
grain will be expensive or cheap.
As government demands are relaxed or pressing,
commodities become less (qing) or more valued (zhong).
Thus it follows that if the prince is not able to control the situation,
it will lead to large-scale traders roaming the markets
and taking advantage of the people's lack of things
to increase their capital a hundredfold.1113
Even though the land may have been divided equally,
the strong will be able to gain control of it;
even though wealth has been distributed equally,
the clever will be able to accumulate it.1114
A clever person may reap the rewards of ten men,
while the stupid person is not even able to hold on to his original capital.
Should the prince be unable to adjust this situation,
there will develop a hundredfold difference in people's standard of living.
Now if people are too rich, salaries cannot be used to employ them;
if they are too poor, punishments cannot be used to intimidate them.1115
When laws and orders are not executed
and the multitude is not well governed,
it is because great inequality exists between rich and poor.
Moreover, the prince should calculate the amount of grain needed
and then see that fields are cultivated
and grass lands1116 are opened in order to obtain the required amount.1117
Then for what each person eats
there will be a certain amount of land.
Taking into account basic production figures and the amount of grain in storage, there should be enough.
If people, nevertheless, are still starving for want of something to eat, what can the reason be?
It is because grain is being hoarded.
Now,1118 when the prince mints coins to establish a money supply,
the people all accept them as a medium of exchange.
For each person there is a certain number in the hundreds or thousands.
If people's daily requirements are still not met and the money in circulation is insufficent,
what can the reason be?
It is because the money has been accumulated1119 as profit.
Under such circumstances, if the prince is unable to disperse these hoards,
bring surpluses and shortages into balance,
and divide up wealth that has been accumulated,
so that the amount of money in circulation accords with the requirements of the people,
then even though he may be unceasing in his efforts to strengthen essential production, encourage planting,
and mint money every day,
it will only result in the people below enslaving each other.
How can this be considered good government?
When there is a bumper harvest,
no one can sell grain in the market,
and dogs and pigs eat the food of people.
When there is a bad harvest,
grain is sold in the market for ten strings (jiang) of cash per fu,1120
and the roads are filled with starving people.1121
Even so, how can it be that the productivity of the soil is truly inadequate
and deficiencies in the food supply really exist?
Indeed, when the price of grain is so cheap in one year
that dogs and pigs eat the food of people,
it results the following year in people not having enough.
When goods are so cheap,
they cannot be sold for even half their cost of production,1122
and for their effors, people are not even able to recoup their original investment.
When goods become expensive,
they cannot be had for ten times their normal price,
and the needs of the people cannot be satisfied.
Even so, how can it be that things are really in short supply
and both current production and reserves are inadequate?
Indeed, when the opportunity for people to make a profit is lost, prices become unstable.
Therefore, those who are good at managing their states distribute their reserves when people do not have enough
and intervene in the market when people have surpluses.
When the people have a surplus of grain, they value it little (qing).1123
Therefore the prince may acquire grain for storage at a low price (qing).
When the people are faced with shortages, they value it greatly (zhong).
Therefore, the prince may distribute these stores at a high price (zhong).
By accumulating stores of grain when demand and price are low (qing)
and distributing them when demand and price are high (zhong),
the prince is certain to gain a tenfold profit,
xx
In general, the great advantage of qing zhong economic policies
is that they make use of what is valued to acquire what is not valued
and what has been acquired cheaply to ease the price of what has become too expensive.
Whether or not things are plentiful or in short supply
depends on the season.1124 If princes are stabilized there will be no fluctuation,
but if a proper balance is not maintained, high prices will appear.
Knowing this to be so, the prince
institutes controls in order to maintain stable prices.
He sees to it that in every city of ten thousand households there are certain to be stores amounting to ten thousand zhong of grain
and ten million strings of cash.
He also sees to it that in every town of a thousand households there are certain to be stores amounting to a thousand zhong1125 of grain
and a million strings of cash.
In the spring this is used to support plowing
and in the summer to suport weeding.
Digging forks and plows, tools and implements,
seed grains and food rations,
all are supplied by the prince.
Thus big traders and families engaged in hoarding are unable to force exactions from our people.
Why does the prince do this?
It is because he is very conscientious about nurturing the essential industry of agriculture.
He uses spring grants to collect silk;
he uses summer loans to acquire grain from the autumn harvest.
In this way the people do not waste their efforts
and the state does not lose its opportunity for profit.
In general the five grains
determine the value of all other things.
Should grain be expensive, other things will be cheap;
should grain be cheap, other things will be expensive.
When the two vie with each other
there can be no stability.
Therefore the prince controls the alternating superiority of grain
and other things by intervening in the market when prices are unstable.
Thus the multitude has no special taxes imposed upon it,
yet the profits of the country go to the prince.
Now, placing a special tax on houses and verands
means harming construction.1126
Placing a special tax on the six domestic animals
means killing the living.
Placing a special tax on cultivated fields
means restricting their cultivation.
Placing a special levy on adult males
means the falsifying of their true numbers.
Placing a special levy on households favors
those blessed with abundance.1127
This five special taxes and levies cannot be used all at once.
Those who have become kings have used them, but never all of them at the same time.
Therefore, a true son of Heaven bases his special revenue income on money.
Ordinary feudal lords base it on food.
In a normal year, if ten cash is added to the price of each shī128 of grain
and each adult male were to consume four shi of grain per month,
this would produce an extra tax revenue of forty cash per month.1129
If an adult female were to consume three shi per month,
the extra tax revenue would amount to thirty cash,
and if a child were to consume two shi,
it would amount to twenty cash.
In a bad year when the price of grain is expensive,
if one were to add twenty cash per shi,
then the extra tax revenue would amount to eighty cash per adult male,
sixty for an adult female,
and forty for a child.
This is not a case of a prince issuing orders for a special per mu harvest1130 tax on households,
but rather it is the case that by his maintaining control over current agricultural production and the collection of reserves,
no one, whether male or female, old or young, may escape paying his or her share.
If one person purchases food grain from a government granary,
the prince will receive more than he would from [the imposition of a special per capita tax] on ten people.1131
If ten people purchase their food from a government granary,
he will receive more than he would from such a tax on a hundred people.
If a hundred people were to make such a purchase,
he would receive more than he would from a thousand people.
Indeed, when things are plentiful, they will be cheap;
when they are scarce, they will be expensive.
When they are spread about, supply will exceed demand;
when they are concentrated, demand will exceed supply.
Knowing this to be so,
the prince pays attention to his country's surpluses and shortages and manages its wealth and goods.
When grain is cheap, he exchanges money for food.
When hemp and silk cloth are cheap, he exchanges money clothing.
He pays attention to the relative value (qing zhong) of things and manages them in order to maintain price stability.
Therefore, the expensive and cheap may be harmonized,
and the prince reaps his profits.
When a state has a country of ten thousand chariots to its fore
and another of a thousand chariots to its rear,
it is said to be a state that is being resisted from in front.
When a state has a country of a thousand chariots to its fore
and another of ten thousand chariots to its rear,
it is said to be a state that is being spurred on from behind.
When a state's territory forms a square
with hostile powers on all sides,
it is called a "crossroads state."1132
A ruler who occupies such a crossroads position with a hundred chariots
is said to be a prince who must depend on others to eat.
If he is one with a thousand chariots,
his territory will be pared down by two-thirds.1133
If he is one with ten thousand chariots,
his territory will be pared down by one-third.
What is meant by saying that a ruler who occupies a crossroads position with a hundred chariots is a prince who must depend on others to eat?
Now, if a ruler has only a hundred chariots to occupy such a crossroads, he will be threatened and surrounded by states of a thousand or ten thousand chariots.
If the princes of these large states are not on good terms with each other
and mobilize their troops for attack,
they are certain to consider this small state either as something to be used as an obstacle to aid their defense or as a screen to hide their offense.
If there is any advantage to be gained from this, the prince of the small state will not be the one to enjoy it.
His great ministers will have been killed abroad,
but he still must distribute land and their families in recognition of these ministers' merit.
His knights in array will have been bound and taken captive,
but he still must distribute rewards and salaries to them.
Thus his territory will be exhausted in the recognition of merit and the granting of rewards,
and his tax revenues and stores1134 will all be consumed in supporting the orphaned children of his great ministers and knights.
Such a person is ranked as a prince in name only,
being without any land in his possession.
Although his designation may be that of someone who has control of a hundred chariots,
in fact he does not have the use of a single foot of territory.
Therefore, he is said to be a prince who must depend on others to eat.
Such being the case, when the resources of large countries have been depleted
and small countries are completely exhausted,
what can be done to provide them with what they need?1135
The answer is that
a hundred-chariot state
must take charge of all loans and institute a system of contracts based on fiscal data,1136
take advantage of the rise and fall of prices during the four seasons,
and control them by utilizing the stabilizing features of qing zhong economic policies.
Thereafter, a hundred-chariot state may be provided with what it needs.
A thousand-chariot state must maintain complete contol
over sources of natural resources,
where tools and implements are made,
and where wealth and goods are produced,
and pay attention to whether the harvest is good or bad
when setting salaries.
Thereafter, a thousand-chariot state will have all it needs.
A ten-thousand-chariot state
must maintain control whether the harvest is good or bad,
take advantage of whether the people are feeling relaxed or hard pressed,
and make correct use of orders
in order to maintain overall economic stability.
Thereafter, the needs of a ten-thousand-chariot state will be fully met.
Jade comes from the Yuzhi,1137
gold from the Ru and Han rivers,1138
and pearls from Chiye.1139
From east to west and north to south,
the distance from Zhou was 7,800 li.1140
Rough terrain and rivers blocked the way,
neither boats nor carts being able to make it through.
Since the road was long
and reaching these places was difficult,
the former kings took advantage of the preciousness of such things.
They made pearls and jade the highest form of money,
gold was placed next,
and knife and spade copper coins were placed at the bottom.1141
Holding on to these three forms of money will not help one feel warm,
nor will attempting to eat them help satisfy one's hunger.1142
The former kings simply used them to control wealth
and goods in order to manage their people's affairs
and pacify the empire.1143
Nowadays, when the prince levies special taxes and other demands on the people,
if his order says that
payment must be made in full within 10 days,
the prices for property and goods will fall by 10 percent.
If the order says that
payment must be made in full within eight days,
the price will fall by 20 percent.
If payment must be made in full within five days,
prices will fall by 50 percent,
but if the order is issued in the morning and payment must be made in full by that night,
prices will fall by 90 percent.
Knowing this to be so, the former kings
did not place demands directly on the multitude of people but used administrative orders manipulating prices to obtain special revenue.1148

div.head: 22.4山國軌第七十四管子輕重七。

p.seg: "There are statistics," replied Guanzi,
"for cultivated land,
for population,
for your needs,
for the daily requirements of people in general,1145
for the money supply,
for districts (xiang),
for outer regions (xian),
and for the entire state.
It is impossible
for one to be ignorant of
statistical methods."
"How does one apply statistical method?"
asked Duke Huan.
"How much cultivated land does a specific district have?"
came Guanzi's reply.
"What are the normal requiements for people?
How much is the price of grain?"
Then continuing,
"What is the population of a specific outer region?
How much cultivated land does it have?
How much coinage is required to meet its needs?
What must the price of grain be to correspond to the amount of cash in circulation?
How much grain will be left in excess of estimated consumption each year?"
And again,
"In a specific district,
how much cloth do women produce on an annual basis?
What is the current value of this production?
After people have been supplied with clothing and bedding,
how much is left over each year?
There should also be separate categories of figures
corresponding to other types of land."
"What do you mean by this?"
asked the duke.
"There is land suitable for bulrushes and cattails,
land suitable for different varieties of bamboo,
the tan tree,1146 and silkworm thorn, land consisting of low-lying swamps,
and land that has been flooded in order to raise fish and turtles.
Now if the prince is also skilled in managing
and securing these four types of land,
he will be able to extract extra income from their products rather
than extracting it from his people.
If the prince does not utilize statistics
to control ten-gu-per-mu land,1147
then the people will control it.
If these people control the medium of exchange, it will enhance their power,
and they will no longer consider the basic industry of agriculture worthwhile.
Such would be the result of failed policies on the part of the prince
Duke Huan said,
"How does one put these ideas concerning the use of statistics into effect?"
"If one does not keep statistics secret,
those below will control the government on high,"
replied Guanzi.
"What do you mean by this?"
"How much cultivated land does a specific district possess?
How many people must it feed?
What is the extent of women's work in a specific district?
How much excess clothing will be produced?
After each subdistrict (zhou) and village (li) has been carefully examined, the answer may be that
the amount of cultivated land is such and such
and the population is such and such.
Since the population is too large, the cultivated land will fail to meet the need for food by such and such an amount.
Or the answer may be that
there is such and such amount of cultivated land
and such and such amount of excess food.
You must have summary figures for your statistics.
These are called general estimates.
"Thereafter, you should institute a plan to establish a money supply based on comprehensive calculations.
Where the figures for agricultural production normally exceed what is needed to feed the population,
cautiously issue public funds as loans,
providing large amounts to wealthy families
and small amounts for those who are poor.1148
In case of mountain land and intermediate-grade land1149
where each year there is usually not enough food for people,
issue them public funds
in order to meet their normal requirements.
If the harvest is fruitful
and the five grains flourish,
you should say to people with high-grade land,
啍he money I advanced to you amounted to such and such.
Your district's grain is now at such and such a price.
xx
The value of grain will then rise
while that of money will fall.1150
"Since the grain from high-grade land has come under your control
and that of intermediate-grade land cannot compensate for shortages in mountain land, the price of grain will increase tenfold.
However, since those having mountain land have already been issued public funds
to relieve their shortages,
they will not suffer excessive loss.
When the excess grain from high-grade land has come under the control of the government at just the right time,
it automatically causes the price of grain to rise tenfold.
"If the silk textiles produced by women fit state needs,
they may
all be purchased on a contractual basis with payment
xx
The contract will state:
偝ince the government has no cash but has grain,
grain will be used instead of cash.'
In this way you will give back grain to fulfill the contract,
the needs of the state will be met, and grain will revert to its normal price.
"Then once again issue funds in accordance with your estimates to acquire grain for your granaries.
This will again cause the price to rise tenfold.
Inform wealthy families and those that have accumulated proterty:
偝ince the sovereign is about to make a tour of inspection,1151
each of you shall contribute such and such amount of cash.'
Then you should also inform neighboring outer regions:
偲hose of you who have grain are not permitted to move it around.
If there is not enough to meet the needs of the occasion,
then I will lend these peoplē152 food for my men and horses.'
The price of grain within neighboring outer regions on all sides
will then automatically go up tenfold.1153
Later, you should hand down an order stating:
偲he funds that have been lent to wealthy families
shall be repaid in cash
in accordance with the current value of grain.'
Thus the value of garin will fall
xx
"In all of your cities (du) and outer regions,
this utilization of statistics should be carried out accordingly.
Having caused the price of grain to rise tenfold,
return the grain as a loan to be repaid in cash
so that 90 percent of the nation's money supply will be in the hands of the government on high
while only 10 percent will remain with the people below.
While cash is in short supply and valued (zhong) and goods are plentiful and cheap (qing),
buy up goods,
paying for them with cash.
Money will then be in the hands of the people below,
but goods will be in the hands of the government
and increase in value tenfold.
Officials in charge of government storehouses should then sell these goods at their market price
until the price goes down.
"Statistics related to state finances will have been set forth before any goods have materialized,
and become effective the moment that they do.
By taking advantage of government orders to move goods and money back and forth,
there is no need to make any demands on the people in the form of special taxes and levies.
xx
Duke Huan inquired Guanzi,
"Is there a way to
support the state without utilizing special taxes and levies?"
"If you make use of statistics in a timely fashion
and take charge of your natural resources,
what need will you have to place special demands upon the people?"
replied Guanzi.
"What do you mean by 啍ake charge of natural resources'?"
"Springtime
is devoted to people working in the fields or performing labor service,"
replied Guanzi.
"In the summer, fall, and winter,
issue orders permitting
or prohibiting people [access to mountains and marshes].
These are the times when people take advantage of the seasons to exploit natural resources.
They are also the times when prices fluctuate
and when the people can most easily be gathered together.
The prince must enforce the duties of the four seasons."
"What do you mean by 偮uties of the four seasons'?"
asked the duke.
"Whatever people need
in the spring, summer, fall, and winter,
the prince will already have accumulated in his stores.
On the day that spring work is set forth
he will have prepared lined jackets for spring,
unlined jackets for summer,
spades, baskets for moving earth, ropes, winnowing baskets, bags, bamboo boxes, storage baskets, and twine for binding sheaves of grain1154
for so and so many days of work
xx
Households that lack resources of their own
may borrow them.
When tools and implements and such items as bags, bamboo boxes, storage baskets, twine for binding sheaves of grain, as well as public-issue clothing are returned to public storehouses
on completion of the season's work, this1155 terminates people's contracts with the government.
Thus the labor is provided by the peole
while their needs are supplied by the government.
"During the ten most critical days of spring,
do not interfere with plowing.
During the ten most critical days of summer,
do not interfere with weeding.
During the ten most critical days of autumn,
do not interfere with the harvest.
During the twenty most critical days of winter,
do not interfere with clearing the fields.
This is called peotecting seasonal work."
"Good!"
exclaimed Duke Huan.
"I want to establish an office in charge of statistics.
How do I go about it?"
Guanzi replied,
"The plan for controlling salt and iron
is sufficient to serve as a basis for setting up such an office."
"What then?"
"In the Longxia area,1156
issue nine thousand catties of gold,
supplementing it with coins.
For wealthy families use gold;
for those that are poor use coins.
The land stretching from the area around Qishan to the hills marking the frontier west of Zhengqiu
is mountain land.1157
Issue coins there, taking into account the needs of the rich and the poor and harmonizing them.
The area around Shouling and east to Shaosha
is intermediate-grade land.1158
Control it with money,
using gold in the case of wealthy families
and coins in the case of those that are poor.
Once these three types of land have all come under your way,
the price of grain throughout the state will increase tenfold.
"Cattle and horses belonging to the families of Liang Wei and Yang Suo are everywhere in the state of Qi.
I request that we separate them according to the appearance of their foreheads and teeth.1159
Also measure their height.
We should then tell these people: 'The state is about to organize a military force,
and to pull out war chariots,
we are taking your oxen and horses.
Since our government has no money,
we are asking to use grain at market price in exchange.'
Oxen and horses will then be controlled by the government,
while unhusked grain will be in the hands of the Liang and Yang families.
Once these two families distribute the grain,
xx
Guanzi then said,1160
"May I request that we establish price contracts with the people for raising horses,
doubling the amount advanced to those who possess cultivated fields.1161
There is no need to have such contracts within the country proper
since it is only in the border regions1162 that there is the space necessary for their fulfillment.
The number of horses broken to saddle will then number a thousand
and Qi will have all the horses it needs for its war chariots.
In this way its needs will be fulfilled
without having to place any demands on the people,
and special military taxes on the section (qiu) and colony (yi) may be eliminated.1163
"The rise and fall of the nation's grain prices depends on the government.
It also determines whether the price of products of the mountains and forests and tools and implements in public storehouses go up or down.
At the same time, it is the government that determines whether things during the spring and autumn, winter and summer are plentiful and cheap (qing) or in short supply and expensive (zhong).
Conduct an inspection of cultivated fields.
If there are trees in any of the fields,
they should be declared as harmful to grain production.
On all sides within the residential compound, plant mulberry trees.1164
Any others are considered harmful to women's work.
There should be no place for people to look for materials to make houses and buildings, tools and implements,
aside from state controlled mountains.
Thereafter, my lord, you should institute three classes of user fees (zu) for mountains.
Trees that are small enough in diameter to be grasped in the hand or even smaller are for firewood.
Those that require at least two hands to go around them are building material.
Those of three span or more
are coffin material.1165
For firewood the user fee should be such and such an amount,
for building materials another,
and for coffin materials a third."
"If you use your handling of salt and iron as the basis for utilizing statistics,"
said Guanzi,
"it will result in the value of the grain you have in storage being increased tenfold.
Of this, 90 percent will be retained by the prince,
but his people, having sufficient food and clothing, will perform their labor service.
All below will be peaceful and there will be no resentment or criticism.
"When you eliminate taxes on their land
by placing taxes on mountains,
wealthy families that provide their relatives with lavish funerals
will pay huge fees,
while poor families that are frugal in this respect
will pay only small ones.
Wealthy families that build elaborate, palatial mansions
will pay huge fees,
while poor families that live in cottages and thatched huts
will pay only small ones.
When the government on high institutes a system applying statistics to state finances, the people's poverty and wealth
will be kept on a tether.
This is what is meant by using statistics to contol state finances."

div.head: 22.5山權數第七十五管子輕重八。

p.seg: "Heaven displays its changes in terms of the seasons,"
replied Guanzi.
"Earth displays them in term of the products it produces,
people in terms of their work effort,
and the prince in terms of his orders.
If the prince fails to cope with the changes wrought by Heaven,
he will also be at a loss in coping with changes related to Earth and people."
"What do you mean by this?"
"When Tang1166 suffered seven years of drought
and Yū167 suffered five years of floods,
there were people who lacked even gruel to eat and those who were forced to sell their children.1168
To rescue these people,
Tang coined money from the metal of Mount Zhuang,
and Yu did likewise
from the metal of Mount Li.1169
xx
Now the kingly ruler retains 30 percent of the harvest each year and in three and one-third years acquires the equivalent of a full year's harvest.
In thirty-one years, he will have acquired the equivalent of eleven and one-third harvests.1170
Storing away one-third of the harvest
is not enough to harm anyone,
and the peasants will still treat their work seriously by continuing to work hard.
Thus when Heaven sends down harm in the form of fierce droughts and major floods,
people will not end up starving to death in ditches or being reduced to beggary.
This is the way to take advantage of seasonal work in order to prepare for changes wrought by Heaven."
"Good!"
said the duke.
"I wish to put into effect methods for coping with change.
xx
Guanzi replied,
"The red silks1171 produced in the area south of Mount Liang1172
and the bī173 made of Ye stonē174
are not to be found anywhere else in the world."
He then said:1175
"One should use these to corner the nation's grain supply, each year acquiring one-tenth,
so that in five years
the price of grain
may rise tenfold over what it was before."
Continuing on, he added,
"I suggest that you establish a coinage.
Use two years' worth of your reserve supply of unhusked grain to hire labor1176 for the state's copper mines,
set up smelters for casting coins,1177
and bring the prices of your goods into line with those of the rest of the world.
If one's prices are higher (zhong), other people's goods will be dumped on one.
If one's prices are cheaper (qing), one's goods will flow abroad.1178
Therefore one must be in line with the rest of the world.
Having one's goods flow abroad means that one has lost control over the situation.
Having goods dumped on one means that one's plans have failed.
If one is not prepared to cope with changes wrought by Heaven,
people below will seek help from each other
and be forced to become each other's secret slaves.
Such is tha beginning of physical punishments and fines
and the origin of disorder and ruin.
What was equal becomes unequal,
people who were prosperous become impoverished,1179
and the state's grain reserves become empty.
This is entirely the result of failing to cope with the changes wrought by the three, Heaven, Earth, and people."
"How does one," asked the duke,
"pursue methods for coping with changes wrought by these three?"
"When the harvest is rich, store away half of it;
when it is poor, do the same."
"A poor harvest," said the duke,
"is reason for increasing the amount of grain available.
Why store away half the harvest?"
"During bad years it is easy to increase the price.
Once can become ten;
ten can become a hundred.
Bad years should be used to control good ones.
For the same figure at which a single catty (jin)1180 of grain may be sold in a bad year, it is possible to buy ten in a good year.
If one follows this plan for good years, the cost will be reduced by 90 percent
and there will be a ninefold profit.
By making proper provisions in this way during good years, the ability to cope with changes wrought by the three, Heaven, Earth, and people, will come to lie entirely in the hands of the prince.
This is what is meant by a state being able to cope with changing conditions."
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi, saying,
"May I ask about the state's fixed system [of economic policies]?"
"The state has no such fixed system,"
replied Guanzi,
"because its land has different capacities for production."
"What do you mean?"
asked the duke.
"High-grade fields will produce ten shi per mu,
intermediate-grade fields five,
and lower-grade fields three.11ī
The remainder all belong to the category of uncultivatied fields.
In each case a single peasant
can work a hundred mu,
but the price of unhusked grain will vary from one
to ten
to thirty
or even a hundred.
Thus plolicies based on the movement [of grain from where it is cheap to where it is expensive]
will permit a hundred mu to be parlayed into a thousand mu. In this way,
a country of a hundred chariods may be parlayed into one of a hundred,
and one of a thousand may be parlayed into one of ten thousand.
Therefore land has11í different capacities
and the state has no fixed system."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
"Now," continued Guanzi,11ǐ "a small country may wish to become a large one
and a large one may wish to rule the world,
but such s thing will never be possible
unless they both come to understand planning desighed to cope with change."
"Once one has carried out such policies, what then?"
asked Duke Huan.
"If the prince," replied Guanzi,
"understands methods involving the large and small fields,11ì
he need not fear those whose fields are large because his are small,
and if he understands the methods involving the manipulation of prices (qing zhong),
he need not fear those who have much because he has little.
These are major aspects of state planning."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
"Is there a way to use these
to unite the entire world,
control all within the four seas,
and strengthen one's reputation without end?"
"There is,"
replied Guanzi.
"Maintain a secure grasp of statistics,
stabilize the flow of grain,
act before situations have fully developed,
and continue to control them once they have reached fruition.
See that the value of goods goes from one
to ten, and that there is a ninefold profit for one's use.
By employing the method of alternately relaxing and intensifying government demands
as well as polices that manipulate goods and prices,
one may be parlayed into ten
Take this ten and divide it into two parts, setting four-fifths of one part aside as reserves
and using the other part to intervene in the market
with the prince alternately opening and curltailing its operation."
"What do you mean by 匭pening and curtailing operation'?"
asked the duke.
Guanzi replied,
"If the prince does not exalt benevolence (ren),
the statē185 will not receive any support in return.
If the prince does not exalt compassion and respect for elders,
his people will be rude toward their relatives and make light of transgressions.
Such being the height of social disorder,
the prince should request that the one-tenth remaining in the national plan
be used to erect tablets or commemortative gates
and present gifts of money to filial sons in the districts (xiang).
All the younger and older brothers of such filial sons, no matter what their number,
should be exemted from military service.
With the erection of tablets and commemorative gates
and the exaltation of benevolence, compassion, and respect for elders,
people will spend their wealth rather than hoarding it, and goods will become plentiful and cheap.
If, according to plan, one takes advantage of goods being plentiful and cheap to bring them under control,
then five parts in ten will again remain with the government on high,
and if one used the other five parts1186 to activate the market,
it will be like the sun and moon continuing on without end.
This is the way to possess the world for a long time
and may ne said to be the way to stabilize [the flow of grain]."
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi,
"May I ask about methods of instruction?"
"For those who are most knowledgeable about agriculture,"
replied Guanzi,
"one should establish an award of one catty of gold
or an equivalent value in grain amounting to eight shi.
Similar awards should also be established
for those who are most skilled in raising the six domestic animals (liu xu),1187
planting trees,
growing melons and gourds, onions and garlic, vegetables and fruits, and making them plentiful.
The same should also be done
for those who are most skilled in curing people's diseases,
those who are most able to understand the seasons
and predict whether the harvest will be good or bad
and which crops will fail
and which will flourish,
and those who complrehend silkworms
and mulberry trees and how to prevent silkworms from becoming sick.
Carefully listen to what these people have to say and store their information away in public offices.
Moreover, do not let military service interfere with them in any way.
This is a major aspect1188 of state planning.
In meeting the needs of the state,
it will insure that there will be not only enough to cover its expenditures but also sufficient to increase its reserves.1189
xx
Thereafter, one should establish boundaries [limiting the circulation of goods],
adjust the urgency of one's demands, collect and distribute all things,
and keep them under control by making use of fiscal planning
and the expertise of five types of officials."
"What do you mean by 偳xpertise of the five types of officials'?"
asked Duke Huan.
"Experts in the Book of Odes (Shi) may be used to keep records of social events.
Experts in the calendar (shi) may be used to keep records of harvests.
Experts in the Spring and Autumn Annals (Chunqiu) may by used to record successes and failures in political and military affairs.
Experts on sacrifices to the God of Roads (xing) may instruct people concerning travel conditions.1190
Experts on the Book of Changes (Yi) may be used to foretell calamity or happiness,1191 success or failure,
while those who are experts in divination by tortoise shell may divine bad or good furtune, profit or loss.
Anyone skilled in one of these five
should be awarded the amount of land that can be cultivated by a single horse
and clothing equal in value to one catty of gold.
This is the means to keep the prince from becoming confused and reckless.
These fivē192 types of experts can see things very quickly.
His experts on the calendar will give him early warning concerning the days ahead.
Thus the prince never misses opportunities,
his plans never fail,
and everything flourishes.
His experts on the Spring and Autumn Annals1193
observe gains and losses in the distant past
as a means to provide instruction for what lies ahead.
Experts in the Book of Odes record men whose words are never in error.
Experts on sacrifices to the god of roads inform the prince of road conditions and see to it that he makes no mistakes in ritual while travelling.
Experts on the Book of Changes [as well as divination by tortoise shell] foretell calamity or happiness, bad fortune or good so that confusion will not arise.
xxx
"I have now heard about the methods involved in establishing controls over changing conditions,
but what about insuring the stability of the state?"
asked Duke Huan of Guanzi.
"Once the prince has brought under his control all the people with special skills
and all seasonal activities,
he will also have gained control over the methods for predicting gain and loss
and will be able to determine the beginning and end of all things,"
came the reply,
"Everything else can be managed using ordinary methods."
"What do you mean by 匭rdinary methods'?"
asked the duke.
"Food grains are the people's Masters of Destiny (Siming),1194
and knowledge is their chief support in securing a livelihood.
Having the people knowledgeable but their prince ignorant would be like
a prince's subjects being prosperous while he himself is poor,
or he being prosperous while his subjects are poor.
In both cases this may be said to be two sides of the same coin.
The crucial factor in handling affairs of state
lies simply in relaxing
and intensifying the prince's demands,
the way of the prince lies simply in having laws that are appropriate,
and controlling the hearts of people
lies simply in instituting proper restraints."
"What do you mean by 凐aving laws that are appropriate'
and 剫nstituting proper restraints'?"
Guǎnzǐ replied politely:
"As for formal measures and laws
these take precise account of the strength of the people and promote their achievements (in view of this).
Prohibiting fraudulence
is criticising something in the past in order to give warning about the future.
As a result disasters will not sprout or get wide-spread,
and the people will not suffer natural disasters or recrimination."
Duke Huan said,
"Let me hear more about controlling the hearts of people by instituting proper restraints."
"The state of Jin had a minister who was disloyal to his prince
and considered killing him.
This is called a major political offense.
Jin decreed that the families of anyone
who had committed a political offense would never be able to serve the prince.
This was a mistake on Jin's part.
Political offenses in Qi were tried
and the sentences were meted out in accordance with whether one was a major or minor offender.
It was a basic precept that evil should be severely punished,
while goodness should be glorified.
This
may be called Qi's national precept."1195
"Now that we have put into effect a policy of stabilizing prices (qing zhong),
does this complete our plan?"
asked the duke of Guanzi.
"Not yet,"
replied Guanzi.
"We must gain control of a spirit and use it as a treasure."
"What do you mean by this?"
"In the northern suburbs there is a person who dug a hole in the ground
and captured a tortoise that has a value of a hundred square li of land."
"What do you mean by saying that he 偀aptured a tortoise that has a value of a hundred square li of land'?"
asked the duke.
"The person who captured the tortoise
has now placed it1196 in a large basin.
My lord, I request that you dispatch an embassy of ten chariots,
bearing a hundred catties of gold,
to convey an order to this family stating:
飣erewith is the clothing of a great officer of middle rank.
The son of the Eastern Sea has the form of a tortoise.
Since he is residing with you,
we are presenting you with this clothing
to use for the rest of your life.
We are also awarding you a hundred catties of gold.
Since this tortoise is priceless,
it should be kept in a great tower,
and each day four oxen should be offered in blood sacrifice to it.1197
It shall be treated as a special treasure and called Wuzi.'1198
Four years later,
the prince attacked Guzhu.1199
Since the unhusked grain
held by the Ding family was sufficient to feed the troops of three armies
for five months,
the prince summoned Mr. Ding and stated:
"I have here this priceless treasure,
but now I am about to embark on a major campaign,
please take this treasure as security pledge
so that I may borrow your family grain."
Mr. Ding twice performed obeisance toward the northern district [where the tortoise was housed] and sent along the grain
but did not dare accept the treasure as a pledge to secure the loan.
Duke Huan then again spoke to Mr. Ding:
"I have grown old
and my son does not understand this transaction.
You really should accept my pledge."
Mr. Ding then returned home,
remodeled his house, and spread out a new mat to provide housing for the tortoise.
During that fourth year,
when the duke attacked Guzhu,
it could be said that Mr. Ding's grain
really had provided the food necessary to feed the duke's three armies for five months.
Duke Huan then established a tribute system
in which the value of a wenxing was set at seven thousand catties of gold.1200
A niangui was set at four thousand catties of gold.1201
A heibai zhi zi was worth a thousand catties of gold.1202
In general this tribute system
amounted to twice the scheduled income from Qi's land.
Guanzi said:1203 "In times of crisis, this tribute system
should be used to produce treasures [to serve as security pledges for loans].
In times of peace, one should control the flow of goods."
"What do you mean by 偗low of goods'?"
asked Duke Huan.
"If there is speculation in goods by private traders,
the prince's plans will fail and the people will lose their livelihood.
Therefore, those who were skillful in ruling the empire
also extended their control to things other than the two chief targets for speculation."1204
"What do you mean by 啍hings other than the two chief targets for speculation'?"
"A ten-thousand-chariot state
must have a store of ornamental objects with a value of ten thousand catties of gold.1205
One of a thousand chariots
must have a store with a value of one thousand catties of gold,
and one of a hundred chariots
must have a store of a hundred catties.
Using such a store in conjunction with flexibility in one's orders
is said to be taking advantage of the situation."

div.head: 22.6山至數第七十六管子輕重九。

p.seg: "Liang Ju is wrong,"
replied Guanzi,
"If taxes are low,
granaries will remain empty.
If special exactions are light,
weapons and implements will not be forthcoming.
If weapons and implements are not forthcoming,
the feudal lords will have no furs or silks to wear.1206
If the granaries are empty,
knights will be denigrated and not given salaries.
Since, externally, the world would have no furs and silks to wear and,
internally, the country's knights would be denigrated,
Liang Ju's assertions are clearly wrong.
"When a prince possesses mountains
and those mountains contain deposits of metal,
he may use them to establish a money supply, which, in turn, may be used in place of grain to pay salaries.
Thus, the nation's grain supply will be entirely in the hands of the government
and its price will rise tenfold.
The peasants will retire late and rise early and, without requiring any pressure at all,
increase their production of the five grains tenfold.
The knights, with only half their former salary, will be willing to die for their prince,
and the peasants retiring late and rising early
will be unceasing in their efforts.1207
Those who are skilled in ruling their countries
have no need to say "employ them.'
Their people are driven to seek employment on their own.1208
They have no need to say 偈se them.'1209
Their people are driven to make themselves useful on their own.
Therefore among the peoplē210 there is no one who is not used or not employed.
Indeed, Liang Ju's assertions are wrong."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan.
Duke Huan again questioned Guanzi,
"A person
called Qingshi instructed me,
saying,
Why don't you strict control over various types of ability'?"
"What did he mean by exercise strict over1211 various types of ability?'
asked1212 Guanzi.
"Cause the wise to exercise their wisdom to the full,
strategists to devote all their talents to developing stratagems,
and the various craftsmen to use their utmost skill,"
said the duke.
"Will his enable one to rule the country?"
"Qingshi is wrong,"
replied Guanzi,
"If salaries are low, knights will be unwilling to die for them.
If money has little value, knights will take no notice of rewards.
If goods are too cheap, knights will simply trust to luck for their livehood.
When these three incentives to idleness are present within a country,
what can be done about it?
If 70 percent of the grain supply remains in the hands of the government on high,
and only 30 percent is allowed to circulate among the people below,
strategists will devote all their talents to making plans,
wise men will develop their knowledge to the full,
and brave knights will treat death lightly.
What Qingshi had to say is foolishness.
The failure to comprehend qing zhong economic policies
is foolishness."
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi, saying,
"In antiquity, when the people of Zhou possessed the world,
the feudal lords all came to offer their service.
The judgments and instructions of the son of Heaven
were spread throughout the empire only to be subverted by those below.
How did they do this?"1213
"The various princes," replied Guanzi,
"divided up the land and began to take in tribute,
which they traded in the markets.
One of their schemes involved good,
another involved pearls from the Yangtze and Yang rives,1214
and still another involved malachite from Qin's Ming Mountains.1215
This is said to be parlaying a few into many
or the small into the large
and is within the realm of qing zhong economic policies."1216
"Are means to control the empire
totally dependent on qing zhong economic policies?"
asked the duke.
"Now if a country's grain," replied Guanzi,1217
"were to increase in price tenfold but the price of other things remained low, its great officers would tell traders,1218 'You shall send my grain to market for sale and accumulate goods for me.'
Assuming the original value of grain was one,
it will now have increased in value by a factor of nine,
and since grain has become expensive while other things have remained cheap,
