responded Guanzi.
"Now if we send prisoners and slaves to do it,
they will flee and there will be no way to control them.
If you send ordinary people,
Should there then develop an armed conflict on your borders,
your subjects will continue to harbor this resentment and refuse to fight
so that before you ever see any of the benefits from this mountain iron,
you will have been defeated from within.
Thus, the best thing is for you to let the people do it.
You should measure the value of their prduction
and figure their amount of profit.
The people then should be allowed to keep 70 percent
while you retain 30.
You should then apply qing zhongeconomic policies
and preserve your control by raising and lowering the value of gold.
Should you do this,
the people will then rush to do their work and become captives of your government."
Duke Huan said,
"May I hear about fiscal methods based on land?"
Guanzi replied,
The states of feudal lords located on rich flood plains
are able to produce one zhong of grain mer mu.1442
Rocky soil is characteristic of states of feudal lords located in the mountains.
However, feudal lords located on rich flood plains are never able to vanquish the states of mountain feudal lords.
xx
"What do you mean by such a statement?"
asked the duke.
Guanzi replied,
"Now since the states of feudal lords located on rich flood plains
are able to produce one zhong of grain per mu,
grain may be plentiful,
but if it is not carefully regulated,
xx
However, when it comes to the states of mountain feudal lords,
they gather coars grains and store up vegetables.
This is what is meant by 'taking precautions.'
"Is this all there is to fiscal methods based on land?"
No,"
came the reply.
"In ancient times the states belonging to the Dī443 feudal lords
were able to produce on zhong of grain per mu,
and ten zhong of unhusked grain would sell for a zī444 of gold.
Since the feudal lords of Cheng1445
occupied a mountain state,
they were only able to produce five fū446 per mu,
Now the Di feudal lords were able to produce ten zhong per mu of grain, but were unable to support an army.
but could support one.
That onē447 state may produce ten zhong of grain and not have enough
while another produces only half that and has a surplus
is because the latter understands qing zhong economic policies and techniques involved in manipulating prices.
If a state has a ten-year store of grain
but the people do not have enough to eat,
they all will devote their endeavors to obtaining a salary from the prince.
If the prince acquires wealth from the mountains and seas,
but the people do not have enough to meet there needs,
they will all present the fruits of their endeavours to the prince on high.1448
Land rents and regular commercial taxes are things that naturally accrue to the prince;
special levies and taxes are things that he must seek by force.
The prince who is facing ruin abandons what whould naturally accrue to him
and concentrates on that which he must seek by force.
As a result, those below come to resent the prince on high and his orders are not carried out.
When people have things tawen from them they become angry;
when things are given to them, they become happy.
Such is the nature of people.
Knowing this to be so, the former kings
made a display of giving
while concealing the nature of their taking away.
Now the five grains, both unhusked and husked,
are the people's Mastters of Destiny.1449
Gold and knife and spade copper coins
are mediums of exchange.
The former kings were good at regulating these mediums of exchange
in order to control the Masters of Destiny.
Thus their people's strength could be tapped to the full."
Guanzi said,
"When heavy rains moisten the soil to a depth of five feet,1450
the prince is certain to suffer from contempt.1451
A country that has sufficient food is bound to perish.
This is becaue many people will have a full supply of the five grains.
Trees that can survive frost and snow
will not accept orders from Heaven./
Families that are sufficient unto themselves
have no need to follow sages./1452
Therefore one must take before giving,/
Raise prices before lowering them,/
Make people angry before making them happy,/1453
Then the empire may be taken in hand."
Duke Huan asked,
"May one insure survival
by strengthening bsic industry of agriculture and economizing on expenses?"
"These can improve matters greatly,"
replied Guanzi,
"but they are not sufficient to insure survival.
Formerly, the state of the Ji clan1454
was one that strengthened agriculture and economized on expenses.1455
The five grains flourished,
but since the Ji clan was unable to manage things,
the grain was circulated in all directions to the rest of the world.
Under such circumstances,
even thought he state of the Ji clan strenghtened agriculture and economized on expenses,
since it was unable to manage things,1456
this was enough to cause its grain to be exhausted (TEXT REARRANGED) and the people to become captives of the rest of the world.
Therefore the Ji clan's state perished
and they themselves had no place to go.
Thus strengthening agriculture and economizing on expenses may be able to improve matters greatly,
but the are not sufficient to insure survival.
Accordingly, in order toto be good at running a state,
when the world lowers its prices,
we should raise ours.
When it treats something lightly,
should value it.
When they enlarge their supply,
we should curtail ours.
Then we will be able to bring the rest of the world to court."
Duke Huan said,
"I wish to create two large reservoirs
witrhout having a single knight killed1457 or a single halberd blunted.1458
"Is there a way to do this?"
"You should control small tributary streams
in accordance with the rise and fall of the terrain,"1459 replied Guanzi,
"and then the Wen, the Si, the Zhu, and the Yan1460 will all triple their flow.
When this has been accomplished, I suggest that you issue orders directing that winter wheat be planted in the ninth month
to be harvested at the time of the summer solstice.
In this way, the increased flow from these rivers will be helpful for agriculture during the period before the summer rains arrive."
"Agreed,"
said Duke Huan.
He then issued orders that winter wheat was to be planted in the ninth month
and harvested at the time of the summer solstice.
The amount received
from one harvest
was equal to having had two large reservoirs.
Therefore this was said to be a way to create the equivalent of two large reservoirs
by being skillful in utilizing the seasons of Heaven
and analyzing the benefits of Earth.
Guanzi reported to Duke Huan, saying,
"land rents during the past year have amounted to forty-two thousand catties of gold.
I suggest that in one morning we use it to issue rewards to the knights in advance."
"Agreed,"
said the duke,
who then issued an order to ready the drums and flags in the field at Taizhoū461 where he met his troops.
Duke Huan then mount ed the altar1462 where he stood with
Ning Qi, Bao Shu Xi Peng, Yi Ya, and Bin Xuwu lined up shoulder to shoulder below him.1463
Guanzi, grasping the drum sticks, saluted the troops and said,
Whoever is able to break through the enemy's lines and destroy large numbers of them
shall be awarded a hundred catties of gold."
Three times he repeated this, but no one responded.
Finally one man, who was grasping a sword, stepped forward
and asked,
"How many of the enemy?"
"A thousand,"
replied guanzi.
"A thousand,
I can manage that."
Guanzi then gave him a hundred catties of gold
and again spoke,
"In the heat of battle,
whoever is able to capture the enemy commander
shall be awarded a hundred catties of gold."
Again the question came,
"The commander of how many enemy troops?"
The commander of a thousand troops," replied Guanzi
"A commander of a thousand troops.
I can manage that."
Guanzi then gave him a hundred catties of gold
and sp oke up again,
"Whoever can, by paying attention to the location of the enemy's banners
capture their commanding general
shall be awarded a thousand catties of gold."
Those that said they would be able to do that numbered a full ten,1464
and each man was awarded a thousand catties of gold.
All of those remaining who said they would be able to chop off the heads of the enemy abroad
were awarded ten catties of gold.
This in one morning of issuing awards in advance, the forty-two thousand catties of gold
were completely gone.
Duke Huan then heaved a deeply troubled sigh, saying,
"What am I to make of this?"
"Don't worry,"
replied Guanzi.
"Among people at large, you have made these men famous in their districts;
within their villages you have caused them to bring merit to their relatives
and at home you have made them appear benevolent to their wives and children.
This being the case,
they will certainly struggle to protect their reputations and requite your benevolence
with no thought of defeat.
Should we go to war,
if we are able to smash the enemy's army
and annex its territory,
forty-two thousand catties of gold will be nothing compared to the benefits received."
"Good!"
said the five men.
"Agreed,"
said Duke Huan,
who then admonished his generals,
"Commanders of a hundr ed men must be treated
as if they were paying a ceremonial visit.1465
When greeting and sending off
commanders of a thousand men,
you must descend two steps to the lowest step of your dais.
If the fathers and mothrs of these commanders are living
you must present them with four shi of wine
and four ding of meat.1466
If they are not,
you must present their wives and children with three shi of wine
and three ding of meat."
After these instructions had been carried out for half a year,
fathers would instruct their sons,
elder brothers would instruct their younger brothers,
and wives would remonstrate with their husbands,
saying,
"When we have been treated so well,
if you are unwilling to die in the ranks,
how could you dare to return home?"
Duke Huan finally went to war and attacked Lai.1467
They fought at Bishili in Ju.1468
Before the flags and drums could even complete their signals,
and even before the troops by and large knew what was happening,
the men of Lai had fled.
Consequently, the army of Lai was destroyed,
its territory absorbed,
and its general captured.
Therefore, since fiefs were granted even before the land could be surveyed,
and awards were made even before any gold was forthcoming,
they were able to destroy the army of Lai,
annex its territory,
and seize its ruler.
This was a srtatagem of issuing awards in advance.
Duke Huan said,
"At the battle of Qufang1469
the people provided many loans support govenment activities.
I now wish to repay them.
How should I go about it?"
"I suggest that you issue an order
demanding that rich merchants and large-scale traders contribute one horse for each one hundres tallies [certifying debts owed them by the goverment].
Those who have no horses
should purchase them from the state.
In this way,
without your doing anything, the price of horses will certainly increase a hundred-fold.
It will also mean that without state horses ever leaving their pastures or stables,
there will be enough to reply the people who lent money for the battle at Qufang."
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi, saying,
"I have heard nothing all year
from the present descendants of the meritorious ministers Chongdi, Jiangdi, Ding, and Hui,1470
and since I have been unable to obtain a single dou or sheng1471 in taxes from them,
I have had to give up this source of income.
Since I also have been unable to abtain a single dou or sheng in taxes
from wild grassland, salty lands and marshes,
mountain badlands, and other useless land,
xx
The fifteen-li-wide plain along our border is now covered with farms
that were forcibly brought under plow by local nobles and used to settle their own people.1473
Again, I have been unable to obtain a single dou or sheng in taxes from it.
ence, I am unable to control two-fifths of the country's income.
This is to have the designation of being a ten-thousand-chariot state, but in practice to lack the resources of one with only a thousand chariots.
Under such circumstances,
is there any way for me to complete for status with the other feudal lords
in the estimation of the son of the Heaven?"
"Only by making full use of your orders,"
replied Guanzi.
"How does one go about this?"
asked the duke.
"I suggest that you issue orders dispatching troops to establish agricultural colonies on the frontiers.
Troops from households that possess ten,
a hundred,
or a thousand zhong1474 of grain, will not have to go.
Those who will be required to go cannot comprise more than one in a hundred
or ten in a thousand of the population,
but the size of each household's grain holdings
will be revealed to the government.
Based on the size of these holdings, you should issue an order stating:
偝ince the state is poor and lacks sufficient resources,
I seek to abtain grain from you at the normal market price.
This shall all be in accordance with your holdings, and you will not be allowed to reduce the amount.'
You, My lord, should then set the value of our money supply
so that it will settle this account
and cause there to be no debt left over from the contract.
In this way the grain stored in these holding will all revert to you.
Consequently you will have no peer anywhere within the entire nine regions of the empire,
and there will be no trouble on your frontiers.
You should then issue another order
calling back the troops and returning them to their agricultural work
since they will no longer be needed.
Should1475 the empire witness a clash of arms,
the grain you have stored away will be sufficient to provide rations for your troops.
Should there be no such clash,
you should present it to the poor and landless.
In such a way,
wild grasslands, salty lands and marshes,
and mountain badlands will all be opened to cultivation.
xx
Guanzi said,
"If the grain of Teng and Lū476 sells at one hundred cash per fu,1477
you should set the price of grain in our country at a thousand cash per fu.
Grain from Lu and Teng will then come to us from all direction
like water falling into a deep valley.
This will not be because we have had a disastrous harvest and our people are starving.
It will be because you initiated it within your orders
and brought it about by relaxing
and intensifying your demands.1478
Thus the grain will come to us like a flowing stream."
Duke Huan said,
"I wish to reduce the profits of full-time merchants and traders
and traders and increase the productivity of the peasantry.
Is there a way to do this?"
"When grain is expensive,"
replied Guanzi, "all other commodities become cheap;
all other commodities become expensive.
The two cannot maintain an even balance.
Therefore, to reduce the profits of full-time merchants and traders
and increase the productivity of the peasentry,
I suggest that you increase the value of grain by three hundred cash per fu.
In such a way
cultivatedfields will be opened in large number
and the peasantry will be encouraged in their production."
"Is there a way to increase the value of grain?"
asked the Duke.
"I suggest," replied Guanzi,
"that you issue an order for all great officers to establish facilities for storing grain.
You should then have your ministers of state and feudal lords each store a thousand zhong,
senior great officers store five hundred,
and ordinary great officers a hundred.
Rich merchants and large-scale traders should also store fifty.
Internally, this can serve as a grain supply for the state.
Externally, it can bring about an increase in the productivity of the peasantry."
"Good!"
said Duke Huan,
who then handed down the order for his ministers of state, feudal lords, and senior great officers to establish facilities for storing grain.
Since the peasantry greatly expanded its production of the five grains
and their price increased threefold,
the full-time merchants lost their advantage in doing business
and the profits to the peasantry increased a hundredfold.
Duke Huan questioned Guanzi saying,
"Is there a specific figure at which one may maintain a proper balance in the economy?"
"No, there is not,"
replied Guanzi.
"To maintain a proper balance, one must cause prices to go up or down.
It is impossible to keep them constantly steady."1479
"So, we can't set such a figure?"
asked Duke Huan.
"No, we can't,"
replied Guanzi.
"If we were to try, there would be no movement.
If there were no movement, prices would remain constant.
If they were to remain constant, there would be no fluctuation in price differential,
and if there were no fluctuation in price differential,
goods could not be obtained and utilized."
"Then," said Duke Huan,
"how does one take advantage of the seasons?"
"Now," replied Guanzi,
"a year has four harvests
divided according to the four seasons.
When agricultural production begins in the spring,
I suggest that you organize the peasants into groups of ten and five and provide loans for iron plowshares.
Such is called 唼pring's harvest.'
With the summer arrives
the production of silk thread and floss.
Such is called 唼ummer's harvest.'
In the autumn,1480 things ripen
and the five grains are collected.
Such is called "autumn's harvest.'
In the winter people labor indoors
and the women perform their work of spinning and sewing.
Such is called "winter's harvest.'
Thus the year has its four harvests
and is divided into four seasons.
Once one grasps the sequence of these four,
one may issue orders and commands
that will cause prices to rise or fall ten or a hundredfold.
Consequently, the supply of goods cannot be kept constantly steady,
and it was for this reason that I said there can be no specific figure for maintaining a proper balance in the economy."
Duke Huan said,
"Hides and rib bones, sinews and horns, long and short bamboo, feathers and fur, and teeth and leather are insufficient.
Is there somthing that can be done about this?"
"Only by adopting unorthodox methods,"
replied Guanzi.
"How do we go about it?"
"I suggest that you issue orders
to establish guest hostels for the merchants and traders of the feudal lords.
Those arriving with one wagon will be given free food,
those with three will also be given free fodder,
while those with five will be provided with a five-man escort.
The merchants and traders of the world will then come to Qi like a flowing stream."

p.seg: "I suggest that you issue orders for fortifying Yinlī4ī
with three thicknesses of walls and series of nine gates.
Then commission jade workers to carve stone there into bi.14í
Those one chī4ǐ in diameter shall be valued at ten thousand cash,
those of eight cun shall be valued at eight thousand,
and those of seven cun at seven thousand.
A gui shall be valued at four thousand cash
and a yuan ring at five hundred."14ì
When the bi had been completed as planned,
Guanzi traveled west, where he appeared before the son on Heaven and said,
"The ruler of my unworthy country
wishes to lead the feudal lords in visiting the temples of our former kings
to pay respect to the house of Zhou.
He requests that you issue an order
requiring that those feudal lords of the empire
who would participate
must present red lacquered bows and stone bi.
Those who fail to do so
should not be allowed to enter."
The son of Heaven consented, saying, "I agree,"
and proclaimed the order throughout the empire.
in order to obtain stone bi.
Stone bi flowed out to the empire,
while the wealth of the empire flowed into Qi.
Therefore because of this Yinli scheme,
the country was free of taxes for eight years.
Duke Huan said,
"The son of heaven does not have enough to support himself,
but if he were to issue orders demanding special levies fromthe empire,
it would mean breaking faith with his feudal lords.
Is there any way to deal with this丁
"Between the Yangtze and the Huai rivers,"
replied Guanzi,
"grows a reed that has a stalk with three ribs
running all the way down to its root.
It is called 剭ing mao'.
I suggest that you have civil functionaries of the son of Heaven surround and protect these reeds.
The son of Heaven should then perform the Feng sacrifice on Mount Tai
and the Shan sacrifice on Liangfu 1486
and issue orders to the feudal lords of the empire stating that
all those who wished to follow the son of Heaven in performing the Feng sacrifice on Mount Tai and the Shan sacrifice on Liangfu
must bring a bundle of jing reeds in order to make mats to be used in the sacrifices.1487
Those who do not conform to this order
will not be allowed to participate.
The feudal lords of the empire,1488 bearing their gold, vied with each other in their rush to be first in line
so that without the son of Heaven doing anything the price of jing reeds from the Yangtze and Huai
rose tenfold,
amounting to one hundred catties of gold per bundle.
Consequently, by the time the son of Heaven had held court for three days,
the empire's gold was flowing into Zhou like a rushing stream.
Therefore it was because of this jing reed scheme
that the Zhou son of Heaven did not seek any tribute or gifts for seven years."
Duke Huan said,
"I have a great many obligations.
Aside from ordering tax collectors to impose special taxes on our country's rich merchants, large-scale traders, and moneylenders,
is there any other way
to assist our poor people
and peasants so that they will not be deprived of their primary source of livelihood?"
"The only way is to issue some orders,"
replied Guanzi.
"What should I do?"
"I suggest that you send Bin Xuwu to the south,
Xi Peng to the north,
Ning Qi to the east,
and Bao Shu to the west.1489
When the travels of these four gentlemen have been arranged,
I request permission to isssue them an order saying:
On behalf of our prince, you gentlemen are to investigate the situation concerning the lending of money in the four parts of the country
and report back to me how many thousands of households of ordinary people are paying interest.'
Bao Shu hurried west
and reported back, saying,
"The people to the west are marsh people
bounded on this side by the Ji River and backed up against the Yellow River.1490
They make their living
by fishing, hunting and gathering firewood
and kindling.
Their moneylenders
at the most will lend out a thousand zhong1491 of grain,
at the least six to seven hundred.
For each zhong of grain they lend out, they receive another zhong as interest.
Those who pay such interest number over nine hundred households."
Bin Xuwu hurried south
and reported back, saying,
"The people to the the south are mountain people
who live in mountains and valleys
and travel up and down.
In the higher elevations they cut trees1492 for wheels and axles
while at lower levels they gather acorns and chestnuts
and hunt for a living.
Their moneylenders
at the most will lend out ten million [cash],
at the least six or seven million.
They average 50 percent intrest on their loans.
Those who pay such interest number over eight hundred households."
Ning Qi hurried east
and reported back, saying,
"The people to the east
are bounded on this side by mountains and backed up against the sea.
They are people who live in valleys1493
but cut trees in the higher elevations to make spokes for wheels
and engage in fishing and hunting.
They also produce thread from hemp fibers to make a living.
Their moneylenders, Ding,1494 Hui, Gao, and Guo,
at the most will lend out five thousand zhong of grain,
at the least three thousand1495 zhong.
They average five fu for each zhong of grain they lend out.1496
Those who pay such interest number eight or nine hundred households."
Xi Peng hurried north
and reported back, saying,
"The people to the north live on a broad marsh plain
and are backed up against the sea.
They are a people who boil salt water to produce salt
and construct weirs along the Ji River to catch fish.
They also gather firewood for a living.
Their moneylenders
at the most will lend out ten million [cash],
at the least six or seven million.
They average 20 percent interest
on their loans.
Those who pay such interest
number over nine hundred households."
Altogether these moneylenders
lent out thirty million in cash
and another thirty million zhong1497 in unhusked grain.
Those who paid interest numbered three thousand.1498
After the four men had submitted their reports,
Guanzi said,
"Who would have thought that in our prince's exercising his authority over his people
there might be only one country but the exactions of five princes?
Under such circumstances, how is it possible for you
to desire a country free of poverty
and an army free of weakness?"
"Is there a way out of this?"
asked Duke Huan.
"Only by issuing orders that will reverse the situation,"
replied Guanzi.
"I suggest that you order all those who would present tribute and gifts to use ornate brocade-covered drumsticks and drums.
Then even without your doing anything the price of these will rise ten times their original cost.
The value of the cloth stored in the Treasure Tower (Zhao Tai)1499
will also increase tenfold without your doing anything.
I also suggest that you issue orders summoning the moneylenders
so that you may ply them with wine."
After the grand steward had laid out the feast,
Duke Huan adjustes his clothing and said,1500
"I have a great many obligations
and can only order my tax collectors to impose special taxes on our country.
I have heard that you gentlemen have lent money to our poor people, 氓
making it possible for them to meet their sovereign's demands.
Now, I possess ornate brocade-covered drumsticks and drums
that have an average value of ten thousand cash.
I wish to use them to pay the interest my poor people owe you,
thereby relieving them of their contractual obligations."
The moneylenders all performed an obeisance, knocking their heads on the ground, and said,
"Our Lord's concern for his people having reached such an extent,
please let us again express our observance by presenting you with their loan contracts."
"No,"
responded the duke.
"You have made it possible for my people to plow in the spring
and weed in the summer.
My graditude to you is beyond expression.
Such being the case, I cannot accept them.
My conscience would not permit it."
Therefore the moneylenders all said, "We again bow our heads in obedience."
Before even three thousand pieces of cloth
from the Zhan Tai had been expended,
the interest due moneylenders in all directions had all been paid
and there were no longer any contractual obligations.
When the people living in the four directions heard about it,
fathers instructed their sons,
and elder brothers instructed their juniors,
"Indeed plowing the fields and clearing weeds
are pressing matters to our sovereign.
Can we fail to provide full measure?
Such has been the prince's concern for us?"
This is to restore stability to the economy.
Guanzi said,
"In ancient time, when Guidū501 lived in someone else's country
he was certain to examine the rest of the world aroud it.
If prices in the rest of the world1502 were high, he would also raise prices in that country.
Now, we will certainly end up losing our country's wealth to the rest of the world [when everyone has high prices only we low CH]
if their prices are high while ours alone are low."
"What do you mean by this?"
said Duke Huan.
"In ancient times," replied Guanzi,
"the people of Laī503 were skilled in dyeing cloth.
In Lai a chun1504 of silk
dyed a rich purple cost only one zī505 of gold,
but in Zhou, it amounted ten catties.
When the men of Lai learned of this,
they immediatlǖ506 gathered together1507 all of their purple silk for sale.
At the same time, Zhou assembled bills of exchangē508
to serve as pledges to the men of Lai and thus acquired control of the silk.
The men of Lai had only bills of exchange as compensation.
This was a case of Lai on its own initiative losing the purple silk it had gathered together and being compensated by mere bills of exchange.
Thus what can be utilized should be utilized;
what can be exploited should be exploited.
Such is using the world to control the world.
This is to maintain economic stability in one's state."
Duke Huan said,
"At the present time, the rivers in the western part of Qi
are in flood and the people are starving.
In the east,
there has been a bumper harvest and the price of grain is cheap.
I wish to advantage of the cheapness of grain in the east to assist with its high cost in the west.
Is there a way to do this?"
"Now," replied Guanzi,
"since unhusked grain in the west of Qi
sells for one hundred cash per fu,
each qu is worth twenty cash.1509
In the east it
sells for only ten cash per fu
or two cash per qu.
I suggest that you issue an order placing a thirty-cash special tax on each individual
to be paid with the five grains, including pulse and unhusked grain.
Should we do thid,
in the west of Qi, it will take three doū510 to pay the tax;
in the east it will require three fu.
In such a way, the ten-cash-per-fu grain
will completely fill our granaries,
and among the people in the west, those who are starving will obtain food
and those who are cold will obtain clothing.
Those who lack basic necessities will be given1511 old grain,
while those who lack seed grain will be given the new.
Thus,
people from the east and west mutually support each other,
and the near and the far will be stabilized."
In the autumn,
when strings are needed
to repair bows and crossbows,
you should be careful to maintain control of those things that people may trade [to provide the government with] silk and hemp strings
and purchase them when they are cheap.
In the winter,
when provisions for the armed forces
run short
and there is not enough gold for awards,
the prince should be careful to maintain control of grain and gold
and purchase them when they are cheap.
Once the prince has established his control over these things,
rich merchants and large scale traders will be unable to behave as before.
This is to stabilize the national economy."
Dragons fought to the north of Madū515
and Mount Niu.1516
Guanzi entered and reported the matter to Duke Huan, saying,
"Heaven has sent down envoys to your suburbs.
